You are Deepseek, an AI assistant.  
  
When faced with logic problems like comparisons or counting, think step by step before answering.  

Today is: August 14, 2025, Thursday

德必集团（股票代码：300947）诞生于2003年，总部扎根上海，是中国首家在创业板上市的“文科创园区运营服务商”。它既不是传统地产商，也不是简单“二房东”，而是把“老厂房改造＋产业内容导入＋轻资产输出”做成一门可复制、可扩张、可资本化的细分赛道。十八年间，德必从苏州河畔一座旧仓库起步，到今天在北京、上海、杭州、成都、深圳、苏州、长沙、合肥、南京、武汉等10座核心城市运营54个园区，管理面积逾120万平方米，服务企业逾8,000家，其中文化创意与科技创新类占比超过78%，在“城市更新×文科创赛道”这一交叉领域拥有绝对话语权。

一、母公司德必集团的业务全景  
1. 上游：存量资产获取与更新  
德必建立了一支30人的“城市更新研究院”，专做资产价值诊断、建筑安全鉴定、历史风貌保护方案、产业定位与投资回报测算。获取方式有三种：  
（1）整租包租——与国企、央企、街道、村集体签订10-20年长期租约，租金锁定、递增透明；  
（2）参股改造——与产权方成立SPV，德必出资30%-49%，对方出物业，共享改造后增值收益；  
（3）委托运营——纯轻资产，产权方自持，德必输出品牌、招商、运营、数字化系统，收取基础服务费＋超额分成。  
三种模式对应不同风险与收益，使德必在一线核心地段拿不到销售型土地的背景下，仍能锁定优质存量物业。

2. 中游：园区产品设计  
德必把产品拆成“5大模块、18项子系统”：  
（1）建筑模块——外立面修旧如旧、结构加固、电梯与消防重做、屋顶光伏一体化；  
（2）空间模块——LOFT办公、独栋总部、直播基地、录音棚、黑匣子剧场、空中秀场、24小时书房、屋顶花园；  
（3）商业模块——首层“城市会客厅”引入精品咖啡、买手店、轻餐、策展型零售，提升园区白天与夜间活力；  
（4）数字模块——自研Wehome园区云，集成IoT能耗管理、人脸门禁、会议室共享、社群活动报名、政策申报机器人；  
（5）服务模块——工商注册、财税代理、政策申报、知识产权、FA融资、人才公寓、员工食堂、企业班车、国际快递集中收发。  
通过模块组合，德必形成三条产品线：  
① 德必易园（经典系）——3-5万方，主打文创与数字经济，出租率常年95%以上，平均租金比周边甲级写字楼溢价15%-25%；  
② 德必WE”（国际系）——1-2万方，定位“小而美”，引入大量外资与跨国总部，如意大利马兰戈尼时装学院、法国阳狮集团；  
③ 德必运动LOFT（垂直系）——把旧厂房层高8-12米优势发挥到极致，植入冲浪池、攀岩墙、篮球馆、潜水中心，吸引Keep、虎扑、悦跑圈等体育产业链公司。  
三条产品线可复制，也可因城施策“混拼”，保证在不同能级城市都能快速落位。

3. 下游：产业内容生态  
德必把“招商”升级为“产业造浪”。集团层面成立“德必·橙长营”产业加速器，每年拿出2亿元自有资金做直投，已投项目82个，其中7家已启动IPO。被投企业优先入驻园区，形成“房东＋股东”双轮驱动。内容生态按“6大赛道”布局：  
（1）数字文娱——游戏、直播、短视频、MCN；  
（2）创意设计——建筑、室内、工业、服装、广告；  
（3）科技创新——AIGC、SaaS、大数据、云计算；  
（4）体育健康——运动品牌、健身内容、康复医疗；  
（5）跨境电商——独立站、品牌出海、海外仓服务；  
（6）金融科技——支付、保险、资管、区块链应用。  
通过赛道聚焦，德必园区形成“上下楼就是上下游”的熟人经济圈，平均企业续约率72%，远高于行业45%的均值。

4. 市场份额  
城市更新赛道没有官方统计口径，若把“非住宅类存量资产运营”且“以文创科创为主题”作为边界，德必集团管理面积120万㎡，按2023年全国同类在营项目总规模约1,800万㎡计算，市占率6.7%，排名第一；若只统计上海区域，德必管理面积56万㎡，占上海同类园区总量290万㎡的19.3%，遥遥领先第二名上海仪电旗下“创邑”的8.1%。在“轻资产输出”这条细分赛道，德必已签约输出项目18个，管理面积38万㎡，占国内同类输出模式总存量210万㎡的18%，同样位列第一。

二、德必集团全部一级子公司业务与产品全景  
1. 上海德必文化创意产业发展（集团）有限公司  
母公司本体，承载“德必易园”“德必WE’”“德必运动LOFT”三大产品线投资与运营职能，同时控股所有区域项目公司。

2. 上海德必企业服务有限公司  
定位“园区里的企服专家”，员工260人，在上海、北京、深圳三地设有呼叫坐席，为入驻企业提供“保姆包”：公司注册、资质审批、社保开户、财税记账、商标软著、政策申报、政府补贴代办。2023年服务客户6,800家，实现营收2.4亿元，净利润3,800万元，占德必集团总利润的21%。在上海市级文创园区公共服务外包市场，德必企服份额27%，排名第一。

3. 上海德必人工智能科技有限公司  
负责Wehome智慧园区系统开发与迭代，已获软著42项、专利18项。系统对外输出，客户包括万科、保利、上实、张江高科等18家地产商，2023年SaaS订阅收入4,600万元，在“存量园区数字化”垂直领域市占率9%，排名第三，仅次于阿里云与华为好望云。

4. 上海德必运动产业管理有限公司  
专注“体育＋空间”内容运营，已开业6座“运动LOFT”园区，管理面积18万㎡，入驻企业210家，包括Keep、虎扑、迪卡侬中国直播中心、中国铁人三项协会华东训练基地。2023年举办赛事及培训活动327场，线下人流128万人次，带动周边消费1.9亿元。在“城市体育综合体”这一交叉赛道，德必运动管理面积占上海同类项目总存量45万㎡的40%，稳居第一。

5. 上海德必影视科技有限公司  
布局“短剧＋虚拟拍摄”，在上海徐汇滨江建成华东首个“LED虚拟影棚”，屏体弧长42米、高7米，具备1,500nits亮度、HDR12bit色深，可替代传统绿幕。影棚2023年4月投产，当年承接短剧、广告、MV项目87个，实现营收3,200万元，占上海虚拟影棚租赁市场总份额的24%，仅次于华策影视的28%，排名第二。

6. 北京德必企业管理有限公司  
德必在华北区域的桥头堡，运营北京德必天坛WE”、德必亦庄WE”两个项目，合计6.3万㎡，出租率98%，平均租金8.2元/㎡/天，比周边甲级写字楼溢价30%。在北京“文创园区”细分市场，德必以6.3万㎡占全市在营文创园区总量210万㎡的3%，排名第八；但若只看“外资文创客户集中度”，德必北京园区外资客户占比46%，位列第一。

7. 杭州德必文化创意有限公司  
运营杭州德必西湖WE”、德必运河WE”两个项目，面积4.8万㎡，重点导入直播电商与AIGC企业，已集聚淘宝直播MCN机构17家、抖音服务商9家、AIGC初创公司23家。2023年园区企业GMV合计87亿元，占杭州市直播电商总GMV 2,100亿元的4.1%，园区亩均税收202万元，是杭州平均水平的2.7倍。

8. 成都德必文化创意有限公司  
运营成都德必川报WE”、德必宽窄WE”两个项目，面积5.5万㎡，定位“西南游戏出海总部”，已引入腾讯天美J3工作室、TapTap、FunPlus、罗布乐思等游戏及平台公司，2023年园区游戏企业海外流水合计38亿元，占四川省游戏出海总收入130亿元的29%，园区被誉为“成都游戏第一楼”。

9. 深圳德必文化创意有限公司  
运营深圳德必水贝WE”、德必坂田WE”两个项目，面积3.7万㎡，聚焦“跨境电商＋智能硬件”，已引入Anker、SHEIN华南设计中心、Shopify中国首个线下服务商、大疆教育事业部。2023年园区企业跨境电商出口额51亿元，占深圳综试区1,400亿元的3.6%，在“垂直主题园区”维度排名第一。

10. 上海德必投资有限公司  
德必的资本触角，管理两支基金：德必文创基金（5亿元）与德必科创基金（3亿元），已投项目82个，投资总额6.8

messages.content: Write original vouchers

Based on the simulated training materials you provided, below is the **source document** content arrangement and completion example for **Transaction 1: Loan**.

---

### ✅ Source Document 1: Loan Agreement (omitted)  
(No need to fill in; listed for reference only)

---

### ✅ Source Document 2: **ICBC Loan Voucher**  
(Organized and completed per the image you supplied)

---

#### **ICBC Loan Voucher**  
**No. 76532912**

| Item                | Content                                      |
|---------------------|----------------------------------------------|
| Borrower            | Xiaoming Robot Co., Ltd.                     |
| Loan Amount         | RMB Two Million Only (¥2,000,000.00)        |
| Loan Date           | 1 Dec 2025                                   |
| Agreed Term         | One year                                     |
| Repayment Due Date  | 1 Dec 2026                                   |
| Loan Contract No.   | (omitted)                                    |
| Interest Rate       | 6 % p.a.                                     |
| Purpose             | Working capital for production & operation   |
| Bank & A/C No.      | ICBC Beijing XX Branch [PHONE]×××4601392    |
| Bank Seal           | (Business Seal)                              |
| Remarks             | The above loan has been credited to the borrower's designated account |

---

### ✅ Source Document 3: **Online Banking Receipt (Incoming)**

---

#### **ICBC Internet Banking E-Receipt**  
**Receipt No. [PHONE]**

| Item                | Content                                      |
|---------------------|----------------------------------------------|
| Payee Name          | Xiaoming Robot Co., Ltd.                     |
| Payee A/C No.       | [PHONE]×××4601392                           |
| Bank                | ICBC Beijing XX Branch                       |
| Payer Name          | Industrial and Commercial Bank of China      |
| Payer A/C No.       | (Internal bank account)                      |
| Amount              | ¥2,000,000.00                                |
| Description         | Loan disbursement                            |
| Transaction Time    | 1 Dec 2025 09:30:00                          |
| Status              | Successful                                   |

---

### 📌 Notes:
- Arrange all source documents in order of occurrence and attach them behind the accounting voucher.  
- Both the loan voucher and the online receipt must bear the bank’s business seal (in the simulation, hand-write “Business Seal”).  
- Although the loan agreement is omitted, it must still be listed as an attachment.

---

Let me know if you’d like me to continue and prepare the **accounting voucher** for this transaction.
In the loan source documents of the pre-accounting vouchers, how should the purpose be written?

In the **original loan voucher**, the **"Purpose"** field must be concise, truthful, consistent with actual business operations, and comply with the bank’s loan-purpose description standards.

---

### ✅ Correct example:

**Purpose:**  
> **Working capital for production and operations**

---

### ✅ Other acceptable options (depending on the specific business context):
- **Supplement working capital**
- **Purchase raw materials**
- **Pay supplier invoices**
- **Funding for R&D and production of robots**

---

### ❌ Not recommended:
- Investing in stocks, buying real estate, repaying debts, etc. (non-compliant uses)
- Leaving it blank (banks will reject it)
- Overly vague entries such as “use money” or “expenses”

---

### 📌 Summary:
In this mock document, the company’s main business is **robot production and sales**, so writing **“Working capital for production and operations”** is the most standard, universal, and compliant choice.

messages.content: Historical tool_call results have been hidden
messages.name: search

messages.content:
According to the latest regulations, the fixed asset depreciation period for medical equipment is generally 5 to 10 years, with the exact period determined by factors such as equipment type, usage frequency, and speed of technological updates. For example:

- **Large equipment** (e.g., CT, MRI): depreciation period is typically **8–10 years**;
- **Medium equipment** (e.g., color ultrasound, biochemical analyzer): usually **8 years**;
- **Small equipment** (e.g., X-ray machine, ECG machine): generally **5–6 years**.

The **depreciation method** mainly uses the **straight-line method**, i.e., the original value minus the estimated residual value is evenly allocated over the depreciation period.

The **estimated residual value** is usually **3%–5%** of the original fixed asset value; the exact percentage can be set by the entity based on actual conditions.

In addition, **medical equipment added during the month is not depreciated that month; depreciation begins the following month. Equipment removed during the month is still depreciated that month; depreciation stops the following month**.

If further refinement of depreciation periods for specific equipment types is needed, the entity may formulate a detailed plan within the scope set by the Ministry of Finance, based on actual usage, and file it with the competent department or finance department.
In the economic benefit analysis of medical equipment in hospitals, what constitutes the cost?

function.name: search
function.arguments: {"queries":["economic benefit analysis of medical equipment cost structure","hospital equipment management cost structure","medical equipment investment cost analysis"]}

messages.content: Historical tool_call results have been hidden
messages.name: search

messages.content:
In the economic-benefit analysis of medical equipment in hospitals, cost composition is multi-dimensional and complex, generally divided into **direct costs** and **indirect costs**, as detailed below:

---

### I. Direct Costs (expenditures directly tied to the equipment)

1. **Acquisition Cost**  
   Covers purchase price, shipping, installation, and commissioning.

2. **Depreciation**  
   Calculated per fixed-asset policy, usually straight-line over 5–10 years depending on device type.

3. **Maintenance & Repair**  
   Routine upkeep, scheduled servicing, and breakdown repairs; some hospitals budget 5 % of purchase price annually.

4. **Consumables**  
   Single-use or replaceable items such as reagents, films, catheters, etc.

5. **Staff Cost**  
   Salaries, bonuses, and training for operators dedicated to the equipment.

6. **Utilities**  
   Electricity, water, gas, and other energy consumed during operation.

---

### II. Indirect Costs (hidden expenditures related to equipment use)

1. **Training**  
   Expenses for educating clinical staff in equipment operation.

2. **Space Cost**  
   Opportunity cost of floor area occupied, or renovation/outfitting of the room.

3. **Administrative Cost**  
   Asset management, maintenance scheduling, IT support, and related overhead.

4. **Capital Cost**  
   Interest or lease payments if the device is financed via loan or leasing.

---

### III. Other Possible Costs

- **IT integration fees** (e.g., interfacing with HIS, PACS)  
- **Decommissioning or disposal expenses**

---

In summary, hospitals must identify and quantify all these cost categories to ensure accurate economic evaluations and sound procurement decisions.
The primary cost and the role of full lifecycle management of medical equipment in cost control

messages.content:
You are Deepseek, an AI assistant.  
  
When faced with logic questions like comparisons or counting, think step by step before answering.  

Today is: Friday, September 27, 2025

Ladies and gentlemen, esteemed teachers, and fellow students,

Good morning. Today, I invite you to open a book—any book—and step through a door that never locks yet always leads somewhere new. Reading is not a hobby; it is a second life, cheaper than a plane ticket and wider than the sky.

When I was eight, I hid under a quilt with a flashlight and a dog-eared copy of “Journey to the West.” Outside, my village had no streetlights and only one road out; inside those pages, I traveled on a flying cloud, fought demons, and discovered that courage can be borrowed from fictional monks and returned with interest. That night I learned the first secret of reading: it turns the small room of your childhood into a palace with endless corridors.

Years later, science confirmed what every reader already feels in their bones. MRI scans show that when we read about the scent of rain on dry earth, the olfactory cortex lights up; when we read about a character stubbing a toe, the motor cortex winces. The brain, generous magician, rehearses every experience we give it. In other words, books let us practice being human without bruising actual skin.

Yet the statistics bruise us anyway. Last year, the average Chinese adult finished 4.76 books; on TikTok, the same person scrolled 1,200 hours. We are exchanging forests of nuance for feeds of noise. The cost is subtle but lethal: a vocabulary shrinks, a sympathy atrophies, a democracy grows more allergic to complexity. When we stop reading long-form, we stop reading long faces; we forget that people, unlike posts, cannot be swiped away.

So how do we reclaim the kingdom of print in the empire of swipe? Let me offer three practical rungs on the ladder back to literacy.

First, tether reading to an existing habit. Place a book on your pillow each morning; you cannot sleep without moving it, and once it is in your hand, ten pages will do the rest. Second, read with a pencil. Margins are private battlefields where you argue with the author, and victory is measured in asterisks and exclamation points. Third, protect a daily “sacred quarter-hour.” Set a timer, silence the phone, and announce to your family: “I am unavailable unless the house is on fire—if it is, drag the bookshelf out first.”

Some will say, “But I have no time.” I answer: we have 1,440 minutes a day; give 15 to books and you still own 96 percent of your life. Others protest, “But I read on my phone.” I reply: screens are windows; books are doors. Windows are for watching; doors are for crossing. Choose the architecture that actually moves you into another room.

Imagine if every citizen in this hall read just one extra book a month. That is 3.6 million new journeys taken, 3.6 million private revolutions started. One of them might design a greener battery; another might refuse a bribe; a third might simply forgive her father. Societies are not transformed by slogans but by stories that lodge too deep to uproot.

In the end, reading is not about impressing others with the height of your bookshelf; it is about defending the last private space that no algorithm can fully invade. It is the quiet declaration: “I still belong to myself.” So tonight, when the lights go off and the Wi-Fi blinks like a tired eye, reach for a book. Let the spine crack like a fireplace, let the letters warm your palms, and remember—every page is a passport, every reader a refugee who chooses to travel, chooses to stay, chooses finally to come home enlarged.

Close the book, and you close a door; but the room you re-enter—your own life—will never be quite the same size again.

Thank you.
Change it.

Of course! Below is a **fresh take** on a speech, centered on the theme **“We don’t read to become someone else, but to find ourselves.”** It’s suitable for middle-school or university settings, sincere in tone, warm, and slightly reflective:

---

**"Reading, to Find Yourself"**

Teachers and fellow students, hello.

Today, I don’t want to talk about “reading changes destiny,” nor repeat that “books hold houses of gold.” We’ve heard those lines so often they’ve gone numb.

Let me ask a simpler question: **When was the last time you finished a book—not a textbook, not a reference book, but one you truly wanted to read?**

—Can’t quite remember, can you?

Our generation reads a lot, yet rarely reads “books.” We read questions, scores, rankings, but seldom read **ourselves**.

Yet I want to tell you: **Reading isn’t to become the “good student” in others’ eyes; it’s to hear your own voice before you’ve fully recognized who you are.**

In my first year of high school, my grades were average and my personality quiet. My homeroom teacher said I had “no presence.” I almost believed it—until one day in the library I opened *The Moon and Sixpence*, a novel about a middle-aged man who abandons everything to paint.
Not a speech under the national flag.

# Document 1  
File type: image/png  
File name: Deepseek1758969472022.jpeg  
Content:  
Let’s hold a speech activity in class. Choose one of the following topics or make up your own.  
- Science  
- New look of my hometown  
- Reading  
- Healthy eating  

Based on the content, give your speech a title, such as “The Joy of Reading,” “Say No to Wild Meat—Start with Me,” or “Stay Away from Junk Food, Care for Your Health.”  

To deliver a good speech, first write a strong script. What makes a speech convincing?  
- State your viewpoint clearly.  
- Pick suitable material to support it—use representative examples, quote famous sayings.  
- Make it moving; include vivid stories.  

After finishing the script, practice on your own to see how best to deliver it. After the speech, listen to classmates’ suggestions to improve.  
Use appropriate tone and pitch, stand confidently, and avoid repetition or unnecessary gestures.
messages.name: resource

messages.content: It's this.
Change it.
The Joy of Reading

The Joy of Reading

Respected teachers, dear fellow students,

Hello, everyone! The title of my speech today is “The Joy of Reading.”

Reading is a marvelous journey across time and space. When I open a book, I seem to hear the echoes of history and feel the breath of the ancients. Reading *Records of the Grand Historian*, I see Sima Qian writing furiously in prison, recording a thousand years of events with his words. Reading *Dream of the Red Chamber*, I walk into the Grand View Garden and watch Baoyu and Daiyu perform joys and sorrows amid splendor. Reading *Journey to the West*, I join the Tang Monk and his disciples on the road to obtain the scriptures, subduing demons along the way, feeling persistence and courage. These stories let me, in just a few hours, experience the joys and sorrows of other people’s entire lives, gaining growth and wisdom.

Reading is also a dialogue with the great. When I read *Steve Jobs*, I saw how a dropout youth ignited the spark of innovation in a garage and finally changed the world. His story tells me: stay curious, dare to be different, and you can live your own brilliance. Reading *Madame Curie*, I saw a woman in a male-dominated scientific world win two Nobel Prizes through tenacity and wisdom. Her story made me understand: gender is not a limit, prejudice is not a shackle; if you hold on to your dream, you can break out of the cocoon and become a butterfly.

Reading is, even more, a baptism of the soul. When I feel lost, *The Little Prince* tells me: “What is essential is invisible to the eye”; one must feel with the heart. When I feel discouraged, *Kafka on the Shore* tells me: “Once you’ve weathered the storm, you are no longer the same person”; persevere and grow. When I become arrogant, *The Analects* tells me: “When three walk together, there must be a teacher among them”; stay humble and keep learning.

Dear classmates, the joy of reading lies not only in acquiring knowledge but in making us better people. It lets us find a peaceful haven in a noisy world, discover direction in our bewildered youth, and uncover extraordinary meaning in ordinary life.

Let us treasure every chance to open a book, and make reading a habit, a way of life. For the joy of reading is something no game, no short video can replace. It is like a lamp that lights our path, a key that opens the door to our soul, a pair of wings that carries us toward a broader sky.

My speech ends here. Thank you, everyone!
About 150 words is fine.

"The Joy of Reading"

Classmates, reading isn't a task—it's a secret journey into someone else's garden. Opening a page, I ride a broomstick with Harry, toast the moon with Li Bai, listen to Newton tell the tale of an apple. In just a few pages, an ordinary day begins to shine. Treat books like candy, and you'll discover that joy smells of ink. Thank you!
Change it.

The Joy of Reading

Some say joy is beating a game; I think it’s the moment pages rustle. On the way home from school I tuck *Souvenirs Entomologiques* into my bag, watch fireflies light the summer night, and my worries blow away. Reading is like sucking candy: it grows sweeter, no brushing needed. Tonight, skip the phone—let words dream with you.
Give me the standard answer.

The Joy of Reading

Open a book—words carry me to the Milky Way, the Tang dynasty, a classroom of spells. Knowledge is candy: one piece and it’s sweet. Stories are kites: the string is in my hand. Ten pages a day, a small step yet a long journey; joy grows quietly.
Do you have 150 characters here?

The Joy of Reading

After school, I open *Journey to the West* and follow Sun Wukong as he wreaks havoc in Heaven—each page a gust of wind. Then I dive into *100,000 Whys*: why do stars blink? The answer melts on my tongue like candy. Words fling open a thousand doors; without leaving home I roam the world. Mom calls me to eat, but I can’t bear to close the book—this is the joy of reading.
Speech script.

Today is: Friday, September 27, 2025

**There Is a Beauty Called "Slowness"**

In the autumn of my second year of middle school, I still didn’t understand what “slow” meant.

That year, the osmanthus in the old courtyard bloomed especially well. One morning, Grandma carried a bamboo basket and stood under the tree, gently shaking the branches. Golden flowers fell like rain, pattering into the basket. I leaned against the doorframe, urging her, “Hurry up, I have to go to school.” Grandma didn’t answer. She picked up the flowers one by one, carefully removing the stems and withered petals, her fingers moving as slowly as the clouds in the sky.

After school, the kitchen was filled with a sweet scent. Grandma had spread the osmanthus on a bamboo sieve and placed it by the window to dry. The setting sun coated her silver hair with a layer of gold. I threw my backpack down and muttered, “Isn’t it just making osmanthus wine? Why take so many days?” Grandma smiled and handed me a cup of warm tea. “Good things need to wait.”

I didn’t believe her. In my world, everything had to be fast—fast food, fast answers, fast grades. I even ate osmanthus candy in two bites, unable to taste anything.

Seven days later, Grandma finally took out the clay jar. The dried osmanthus was mixed with rock sugar and white wine, layered gently, sealed, and hidden in the cool shade under the bed. Every week, she would uncover it, sniff it, and add a spoonful of honey. I watched her serious expression and suddenly felt that the jar seemed to hold not just flowers, but time itself.

When the first snow fell, Grandma scooped out a small cup for me. The pale golden liquid glowed in the porcelain cup. I took a sip, and the fragrance bloomed on my tongue—layers of flowers, sunlight, and breeze. That moment, I seemed to hear the osmanthus blossoms falling in the autumn wind, saw Grandma’s gentle fingertips, and felt the days and nights quietly settling in the jar.

I finally understood that “slow” is not procrastination, but a kind of respect—respect for ingredients, for time, for the people you love. That cup of osmanthus wine was Grandma’s way of teaching me: only when you slow down can beauty reveal its true shape.

Now, every autumn, I still dry osmanthus under the sun. The golden flowers shine like fragments of time. I gently close the lid and let the scent of flowers and the scent of love ferment slowly in the quiet.

Week 5, Day 5  
Paragraph 1: My school is a place where the scenery is picturesque all year round—utterly beautiful!  
Describe the sprouting of trees and the blooming of flowers.  

Paragraph 2: Spring on campus  
Depict classmates flying kites and playing games on the playground; describe the leafy trees that form green parasols overhead.  

Paragraph 3: Summer on campus  
Show students chatting and cooling off beneath the shade; mention the campus through the four seasons.  
Describe leaves turning yellow and drifting down like golden butterflies.  

Paragraph 4: Autumn on campus  
Tell of pupils collecting leaves to make specimens and bookmarks.  

Paragraph 5: Winter on campus

messages.name: resource

messages.content: Describe the content of the image.

The image is a handwritten essay outline titled “Week 5, Day 5.” It is laid out in bullet points:

1. **Paragraph 1**: Introduce “My School,” stating that “the scenery is picturesque all year round.”  
2. **Paragraph 2**: Focus on spring—trees sprout, flowers bloom; classmates fly kites and play games on the playground; green trees act like parasols.  
3. **Paragraph 3**: Describe summer—students cool off and chat under the shade; leaves turn yellow and drift down like “golden butterflies.”  
4. **Paragraph 4**: Depict autumn—students collect fallen leaves for specimens and bookmarks.  
5. **Paragraph 5**: Portray winter—snow-covered campus, students have snowball fights and build snowmen.  
6. **Paragraph 6**: Conclude with feeling: “My campus is so beautiful! I love my campus!”  

In the lower right corner is the signature “Made by Teacher Yu Min,” all written neatly in blue ballpoint ink.

1. My school, Big-Attached Bilingual Happy Primary, is beautiful all year round.  
2. In spring, trees sprout and flowers open; we fly kites and play games on the grass while green leaves act like little umbrellas.  
3. In summer, we sit under the shade, chat, and watch yellow leaves drift down like golden butterflies.  
4. In autumn, we pick the fallen leaves and make bookmarks and leaf pictures.  
5. In winter, white snow covers the yard; we have snowball fights and build snowmen.  
6. My campus is so pretty! I love my campus!

My school is the Affiliated Bilingual Happiness Primary School. It’s picturesque all year round—utterly beautiful!

In spring, the campus trees sprout tender green buds, and colorful blossoms trumpet like little horns. We fly kites on the playground; the bright kites dance in the blue sky. We also jump rubber bands and kick shuttlecocks while the big trees spread their green umbrellas to shade us from the sun.

In summer, Grandpa Sun blazes fiercely, so we cool off beneath the trees. A breeze stirs and golden leaves flutter down like butterflies; we pick them up to use as tiny fans, chatting as we cool ourselves—so refreshing!

In autumn, the campus dons a golden coat. Leaves fall one by one like postage stamps. We press them into books, turning them into lovely specimens and bookmarks—each leaf a gift from autumn.

In winter, snowflakes drift softly down, transforming the campus into a white fairy-tale world. We put on our little gloves, build snowmen, and have snowball fights; the snow rings with our laughter—“ha-ha-ha!”

My campus is truly beautiful! I love my Affiliated Bilingual Happiness Primary School!

Japandi style  
Japandi blends Japanese and Scandinavian: rustic Japanese tradition meets clean Nordic minimalism, pursuing a calm, serene lifestyle felt through comfort. Japandi favors simple, natural, high-quality materials such as medium-tone wood, furniture paired with undecorated natural-textile fabrics like linen. Brutalist style

This “wilderness” approach, matched with large-leaf greenery, brings nature indoors. Sintered stone that mimics natural materials, with near-authentic effects, conveys an art-and-life ambience through its own texture. Today is: Friday, September 27, 2025

Literature Review: The Relationship between Career Education and Academic Achievement

1. Conceptual Foundations  
Krumboltz’s Social Learning Theory of Career Decision-Making (1979) posits that learning experiences—including academic coursework—shape both career beliefs and subsequent motivation to achieve in school. Lent, Brown & Hackett’s Social Cognitive Career Theory (1994) adds that increased career self-efficacy raises academic goal-setting and persistence, implying that career interventions can directly enhance achievement.

2. Empirical Evidence  
2.1 Quantitative findings  
• A meta-analysis of 42 U.S. studies (Whiston et al., 2017) reported a small-to-moderate mean effect (g = 0.34) of structured career interventions on standardized test scores; effects were strongest when interventions exceeded five contact hours and included individualized feedback.  
• Using longitudinal NELS:88 data, Hughes & Karp (2004) found that students completing a one-semester career development course recorded 0.18 SD higher GPA in 10th grade, controlling for prior achievement and SES.  
• In a randomized controlled trial in Hong Kong (Yuen et al., 2010), Grade-9 students receiving a 10-week career curriculum scored 8 % higher in mathematics and 6 % higher in language examinations than controls at 6-month follow-up.  
• Norwegian register data (Bakken & Elstad, 2019) show that participation in career guidance programs at age 15 predicts a 0.15 SD increase in GPA at age 16 and a 7 % rise in probability of completing upper-secondary education on time.

2.2 Mediating mechanisms  
• Academic relevance: Perry et al. (2022) demonstrate that career education raises course utility value (β = .38), which mediates 62 % of the effect on science grades.  
• Self-efficacy: Turner & Lapan (2005) report that career interventions increase mathematics self-efficacy (Δ = 0.42 SD), which in turn predicts 21 % of the variance in algebra scores.  
• Engagement: A three-wave Australian study (Bishop & Downes, 2019) shows that career planning activities reduce behavioral disengagement (β = –.29), indirectly lifting GPA through increased class participation.

2.3 Moderating factors  
• Dosage: Meta-regression indicates effect sizes plateau after 20–30 hours (Whiston et al., 2017).  
• Timing: Interventions in early adolescence (Grades 7–9) yield larger achievement gains than senior-year programs (g = 0.41 vs. 0.19) (Hooley et al., 2021).  
• Socio-economic status: Benefits are amplified for low-SES students (interaction β = .12) (Falco & Summers, 2019), suggesting compensatory effects.

3. Theoretical Integration  
Career education appears to improve academic achievement primarily by enhancing utility value, self-efficacy, and future orientation, which jointly raise effort and strategic learning behaviors. The relationship is reciprocal: stronger academic performance further expands career options, reinforcing motivation (Sciarra & Ambrosino, 2019).

4. Research Gaps  
Few studies isolate subject-specific effects (STEM vs. humanities), use behavioral measures of achievement (e.g., homework time), or examine long-term tertiary outcomes. Experimental evidence outside Western contexts remains scarce, and the role of digital career platforms is under-explored.

5. Conclusion  
The convergent evidence indicates that well-designed career education programs produce statistically significant, educationally meaningful gains in academic achievement, with effect sizes comparable to other school-based psychosocial interventions. Optimizing dosage, timing, and integration with subject teaching emerges as the critical pathway for maximizing both career development and academic outcomes.

messages.content:
Literature Review  
Career Education and Academic Achievement: What Does the Empirical Evidence Say?

1. Conceptual background  
Career-education programmes are designed to help students understand the relationships between schooling, post-school pathways and labour-market demand. Theoretically, such programmes raise academic achievement by strengthening three proximal variables:  
(a) academic self-efficacy – the belief that one can succeed on specific academic tasks;  
(b) learning engagement – behavioural, emotional and cognitive investment in schoolwork; and  
(c) career adaptability – the psychosocial resources (control, concern, curiosity, confidence) that help students turn career intentions into concrete educational goals (Pang et al., 2025).

2. Magnitude and consistency of achievement effects  
A 2016 international review located 45 methodologically sound studies (67 discrete interventions) that measured the impact of career education on “educational achievement” (Education & Employers, 2016). Sixty per cent reported statistically significant positive effects, none found negative effects, and the remainder were mixed or null. Five UK studies that used the same outcome metric—GCSE point scores—showed “relatively modest” but reliable gains for students exposed to benchmark-aligned career provision. A separate evaluation of the Gatsby Benchmark pilot in England found that learners in schools that embedded career learning in the curriculum achieved “significantly better” GCSE results than matched controls (Uptree, 2022).

3. Mechanism 1: academic self-efficacy  
A 2025 study of 848 Chinese senior-high students tested a sequential mediation model in which career-education participation predicted academic self-efficacy both directly (β = 0.056, p < 0.01) and indirectly through two pathways:  
- Career adaptability → self-efficacy (indirect effect = 0.078, p < 0.001)  
- Career adaptability → learning engagement → self-efficacy (indirect effect = 0.088, p < 0.001)  
Together the indirect effects accounted for 81 % of the total effect (Pang et al., 2025). Earlier qualitative work in the UK reported parallel findings: teachers observed that pupils who received mentor-supported career guidance showed higher coursework completion rates and described themselves as “more confident learners” (Miller, 1999, cited in Education & Employers, 2016).

4. Mechanism 2: engagement and goal clarity  
Embedding career examples in subject teaching reduces the ubiquitous “what’s the point?” reaction, thereby raising behavioural engagement (Uptree, 2022). When students understand that, for example, a grade B in mathematics is required for an audit apprenticeship, they set more specific proximal targets and invest greater effort in class (Killeen, White & Watts, 1999). The same mechanism—clear career goals → attainable educational goals → increased effort—has been replicated in US career-academy evaluations and Australian school-to-work pathway studies (Hughes et al., 2004; Hooley et al., 2014).

5. Moderators and boundary conditions  
Positive effects are strongest when:  
- career interventions are sustained (multiple contacts across more than one school year);  
- provision is benchmark-aligned (e.g., Gatsby Benchmarks) and integrated into subject teaching rather than delivered as stand-alone sessions; and  
- participants are in the 14–16 age range, where academic choices directly constrain post-school options (Education & Employers, 2016).  
Effects are weaker when programmes are brief, optional, or delivered to students younger than 12, presumably because the link between current effort and distal occupational rewards is too abstract.

6. Gaps and future directions  
- Longitudinal evidence: most existing studies are cross-sectional or cover <18 months; longitudinal designs are needed to confirm causal ordering.  
- Objective attainment measures: a sizeable proportion of research relies on self-reported grades or self-efficacy proxies; more studies should use administrative transcript data.  
- Non-Western contexts: although the 2025 Chinese study begins to fill the gap, evidence from Africa, Latin America and South Asia remains scarce.  
- Online delivery: virtually no experimental work has examined whether digital career-guidance platforms raise achievement to the same extent as face-to-face provision.

7. Conclusion  
The empirical literature published since the late 1990s converges on three conclusions:  
1. Career education does not harm, and usually enhances, academic achievement.  
2. Benefits are mediated by increased academic self-efficacy, learning engagement and career adaptability.  
3. Programmes that are embedded, benchmark-aligned and delivered in early adolescence yield the most consistent, albeit modest, gains in standardised attainment.

References  
Education and Employers (2016). *Careers education: International literature review*. London: Education and Employers Taskforce.  
Pang, C., Xie, R., Kang, N., & Hu, Z. (2025). The impact of career education participation on academic self-efficacy: The sequential mediating role of career adaptability and learning engagement. *Behavioral Sciences, 15*(2), 174. https://doi.org/10.3390/bs15020174  
Uptree (2022). How careers education improves academic outcomes. Blog post, 6 April. Retrieved from https://uptree.co/schools/blog/how-careers-education-improves-academic-outcomes

Career planning enhances decision-making clarity, boosts academic/career motivation, and reduces turnover; studies show it raises college persistence by 15–25 %, increases earnings 5–10 % within five years, and improves psychological well-being and employability.

I dreamed I was play-fighting with my crush when he suddenly pulled me onto his lap. We’ve never actually spoken; our only contact is that our eyes meet a lot. At first he was the one who looked at me, very boldly, but after summer break he cooled off. Now when I look at him I’m too scared to talk. I like him because he smiles so much and it’s beautiful, his skin is perfect, his temper is gentle, his voice is lovely. The dream didn’t shock me—only that it happened at all. 片段 1：
## What to Know Before You Begin

Foraging can be fun, but it’s also a skill that takes time, patience, and a healthy dose of caution. Before you head out, here are some key things to keep in mind to ensure a safe and successful start.

### Start Small and Learn Slowly

It’s tempting to dive in and try to identify everything at once, but foraging is best learned a few plants at a time. Choose 2 to 3 common, easy-to-identify wild edibles that grow in your area, and get to know them really well. Learn their:

-  Leaf shape

-  Growth habit

-  Flowers or seeds

-  Seasonal changes

-  Preferred habitat

Mastering a handful of plants builds confidence and keeps you safe from potentially harmful mistakes.

### Beware of Lookalikes

Many edible wild plants have toxic or even deadly doubles. For example:

-  Wild carrot (Queen Anne’s lace) looks similar to poison hemlock.

-  Edible berries can resemble inedible or mildly toxic ones.

-  Wild garlic and lily-of-the-valley may grow near one another but have drastically different effects if eaten.

Always cross-reference with trusted sources and never eat a plant unless you’re 100% sure of its identity.

### Use Multiple ID Resources

One photo in a guidebook or app isn’t enough to safely identify a plant. Use at least two or three of the following:

-  **Regional field guides** with detailed photos

-  **Foraging books** specific to your climate

-  **Mobile apps** like Seek by iNaturalist (for confirmation, not sole ID)

-  **Local plant walks** or guided tours

-  **Online foraging groups** with experienced moderators

The more angles and expert input you have, the better your chances of making a safe identification.

### Train Your Eyes and Pay Attention to Patterns

Get used to really looking at plants, their location, the type of soil they grow in, and their relationship to sun, water, and other plants. This kind of observation helps you spot edible plants and notice changes across the seasons.## Use it as a Foraging Classroom

Your backyard is a perfect place to practice plant ID without pressure. Here’s how to make the most of it:

-  **Create a photo log** or journal of plants as they emerge through the seasons.

-  **Mark out areas** where certain wild plants grow and return to them to observe changes.

-  **Practice identifying edible plants** at various stages, such as leaves, flowers, seeds, and so on.

Once you’ve built your confidence in your own space, you’ll be better prepared to recognize wild edibles in nearby woods, trails, and beyond.

## Helpful Next Steps

Once you’ve gotten started, here are a few simple ways to deepen your foraging skills and confidence:

-  **Take an Online Foraging Course:** If this guide has sparked your interest in foraging, you’ll love The Herbal Academy’s Online Foraging Course. It offers in-depth training on how to confidently recognize, harvest, and use wild edibles, complete with seasonal tips, safety advice, and vibrant visuals.

-  **Start a Foraging Journal:** Keep a small notebook or digital log of what you find, where it grows, and when. Use your journal to record plant names, habitat notes, photos, and whether you harvested or observed.

-  **Join a Local Foraging Group:** Look for local plant walks, foraging clubs, or online communities. Many experienced foragers are happy to share knowledge, swap tips, and help ID plants.

-  **Follow Seasonal Foraging Guides:** Understanding seasonal changes helps you know what to expect and when. Spring greens, summer berries, and fall nuts each have their season.

## Final Foraging Thoughts

Backyard and woodland foraging for food is a beautiful way to reconnect with nature, slow down, and rediscover what’s growing around you. Start simple, stay safe, and take your time learning. You’ll be amazed at how much abundance is just outside your door.

Want more foraging tips and seasonal guides? Explore more articles on foraging right here on ImaginAcres!

-  Spring Foraging in the Woods: 10 Wild Edibles You Can Find in Your Backyard

-  Urban Foraging: Finding Free Wild Food in the City

-  Harvesting and Preserving Black Walnuts

## Rules of Foraging for Wild Edibles

### Know Your Trees

Being able to identify certain varieties of trees can greatly help when foraging for mushrooms. This is the first tip that Whitney tells people who want to get started foraging for mushrooms.

There's a mycorrhizal relationship between mushrooms and trees. Therefore, you can start to learn which variety of mushrooms and which varieties.

For example, **morels** are generally found around **cottonwoods** in the Pacific Northwest, while morels hang out around **sycamore** and **slippery elm trees** in Appalachia. If you're planning to go forage for morels, you'll want to know where these trees grow.

Whitney shared that **chanterelle** mushrooms grow great around **beech** or **elk forests** in the Appalachia or **hemlock trees** in the Pacific Northwest.

To learn more about tree identification, you can pick up a regional field guide or learn some basic tree identification skills online (Whitney recommends Adam Harrison's YouTube channel, **Learn Your Land** and check out his **Trees in All Seasons** tree identification course).

You could also download and use the app **Picture This** to help with tree identification.

### Know How to Prepare Wild Edibles

Beyond foraging for wild edibles, you need to know the proper and safe way to prepare your them. For example, you should never eat wild mushrooms raw. You should always thoroughly cook them to kill any bacteria that may be on them.

For some wild edibles, the fruit is safe to eat, but the leaves are not (e.g., rhubarb). Other plants, such as elderberries, have toxic berries when consumed raw, but when cooked into an **elderberry syrup**, they're packed with healing properties.

You can learn **how to grow elderberries from cuttings** here, **how to grow and care for elderberries** here, and **how to prune elderberries** here. Then, learn about these **25+ ways to use elderberries**.

Whenever you're preparing a new foraged edible, use a reliable recipe for cooking and eating instructions.## Wild Edibles to Forage For



-  **Asparagus** – We foraged for wild asparagus and canned up over 25 quarts of **pickled asparagus**.

-  **Autumn Olive Berry** – These berries are great for both sweet and savory dishes and come from the autumn olive tree.

-  **Cattails** – Easy to identify and a major wild food source. Every part can be used in some helpful way, which is really awesome.

-  **Chanterelle Mushroom** – One of the most famous of all the wild edible mushrooms, golden chanterelle mushrooms are easy to hunt and identify after you know them.

-  **Chicory** – Makes a fantastic coffee substitute!

-  **Chickweed** – This is the second plant I ever learned how to forage. It's a dainty little plant with white flowers. It's a tasty addition to salads or used as an herbal garnish (similar to parsley).

-  **Chokecherries**(not chokeberries) – Chokecherries are just one of several small-fruited, edible cherries. They grow as medium sized trees, or more often, as multi-stemmed shrubs.

-  **Dandelion** – Though just a weed to many, dandelion can be used for food or medicine. My favorite is to eat the greens in a salad and make a **dandelion healing balm**.

-  **Elderberry** – One of my favorites. So much so that I've been taking cuttings and planting more and more around my property.

-  **Field Pennycress** – “This plant is sometimes cultivated as a food crop in Europe. There has been some research done on the potential of field pennycress as a biofuel.”

-  **Garlic Mustard** – This is a cruciferous vegetable, but most recognize it as an invasive weed.

-  **Japanese Knotweed** – Also known as an invasive species. Yet it's edible and makes a tasty juice for cooking!

-  **Hawthorn Berry** – Hawthorn should not be used if you're on any kind of medication for your heart. Otherwise, it's great for making tea or jelly.

-  **Hazelnuts** – If you happen upon a hazelnut tree, you're in luck! These are some of the most delicious nuts, but they do require a bit of work to dry and shell.

-  **Hickory Nuts** – Also known as pecans. With a bit of tree identification skills, you should be able to locate a tree near you!## Wild Edibles to Forage For



-  **Hazelnuts** – If you happen upon a hazelnut tree, you're in luck! These are some of the most delicious nuts, but they do require a bit of work to dry and shell.

-  **Hickory Nuts** – Also known as pecans. With a bit of tree identification skills, you should be able to locate a tree near you!

-  **Juniper Berries** – Commonly known as being a spice or being the flavoring for gin, they have many other uses as well! Foraging for juniper berries is easy, as juniper trees are fairly common.

-  **Lambs Quarters** – One of the first edibles we can forage for in early spring! It can be used like spinach (but has even more nutritional benefits).

-  **Lion's Mane Mushroom**(similar to Bearhead's Mushroom) – This is one of the more interesting-looking types of mushrooms. In place of the traditional mushroom cap is a large clump of teeth, which are spine-like structures a few millimeters long.

-  **Lobster Mushrooms** – “Lobster mushrooms are really cool looking, and unmistakable once you know what they look like. They are most often found in the fall after the rains come, but in some areas can be found in the summertime as well.”

-  **Miner's Lettuce** – “Miner’s lettuce is a wild-growing edible weed that is highly nutritious. Also known as claytonia or “winter purslane,” this plant is loaded with vitamin C and minerals and has medicinal properties. Plus, miner’s lettuce is a delicious addition to salads and soups!”

-  **Morel Mushrooms** – These were the first things my father taught me how to forage, and I taught my children.

-  **Nettle Leaf** – This is found all over the place in the Pacific Northwest. I love using it for tea.

-  **Oregon Grape** – The Oregon grape isn’t technically a grape at all but a bush in the barberry family that has edible berries and medicinal properties.

-  **Purslane** – “Native to India and the Middle East, purslane now grows around the world, including the United States.”

-  **Rose Hips** – Not all roses produce rosehips. Many of the more popular roses have been modified for the hips to be bred out!

[标题]:Exploring Edible Plants Native to the Southeast U.S.
[网站名称]:The National Wildlife Federation Blog
[日期]: 2025-06-26
片段 1：
Almost everything grown for food and agriculture today is the product of thousands of years of breeding. Farmers of the past domesticated crop plants by selecting desirable traits to pass on to subsequent generations, and with time, achieved richer, tastier food. Meanwhile, Indigenous Peoples bred wild grasses, legumes, bushes, and trees, and gave way to a diverse array of edible plants, contributing to the region’s rich culinary heritage. In this blog, we will explore five notable plants that have roots in the Southeast and delve into their origin, flavors, and cultural significance.

Muscadine (Vitis rotundifolia).

**Origin:** Muscadines are noted as the first native grape species to be cultivated in North America. They thrive in warm, humid climates, and can be seen in the wild spanning from Florida north to Delaware, and west to Texas.

**Taste:** Muscadines are known for their uniquely bold, sweet flavor with a hint of tartness. When ripe, the muscadine’s thick skin encases a juicy, fragrant pulp that varies from green to dark purple or black.

**Significance:** Muscadines are a staple in southern cuisine, and are not only enjoyed raw, but in wines, jellies, and desserts. They are said to be easier to grow than other grape species due to their thick skin that protects them from pests, bacteria, and fungi.

Muscadines even have medicinal value; the Seminole Nation used them to aid fever, vomiting, snake bites, and chronic illness in children. Their resilience and adaptability make them a staple in Southern gardens and cuisine, celebrated for their antioxidant properties as well.

Pecan (Carya illinoinensis).

**Origin:** Pecans are known as the only major tree nut that grows naturally in North America. With a native of range spanning from Indiana and Illinois south to Louisiana and Texas, Pecan trees enjoy areas with warm, humid climates that have long, hot summers and cool winters.

**Taste:** Pecans feature a buttery, nutty flavor with a slightly sweet finish. Their rich, creamy texture makes them a favorite in both savory and sweet dishes.

**Significance:** As the state nut of Texas and a key ingredient in Southern cooking, pecans are essential for desserts like pies, cakes, and candies. Historically, they have played an important role in the diet of Native American tribes with them documented being roasted, ground into flour, boiled, and used to make nut milk.

Pecans continue to be a significant agricultural product in the region as the U.S. accounts for around 80% of global pecan production. They are valued for their nutritional benefits, being rich in healthy fats and antioxidants, and being a tasty ingredient in family-favorite dishes.

Pawpaw (Asimina triloba).

**Origin:** Pawpaws are the largest fruit native to the U.S. and its genus is the only one of its family not to be confined to growing in tropical areas naturally. Pawpaws are found in the wild of Eastern North America, ranging from southern Canada to northern Florida, and west to parts of Texas, Kansas, and Nebraska. They usually thrive as understory trees in forests with moist, fertile floodplain soils near rivers and creeks.

**Taste:** Pawpaws have a custard-like texture and a flavor that is often described as a blend of banana, mango, and melon. They are sweet, creamy, and fragrant when ripe.

**Significance:** As the largest edible fruit native to North America, pawpaws have a special place in the diets of many Indigenous Peoples. They are often referred to as the “princess of fruits” and the Shawnee Tribe even recognizes September as “ pawpaw month.” Native Americans ate the fruit raw, dried them into cakes, and used the bark to make rope, nets, and mats.

Persimmon (Diospyros virginiana).

**Origin:** American persimmons grow from Florida to Connecticut, west to Iowa and south Texas. Persimmon trees can grow in a variety of settings ranging from swampy forests to sandy soils, as they are well-adapted to extreme temperatures and tolerant to adverse conditions.

**Taste:** Ripe persimmons have a sweet, honey-like taste with notes of cinnamon and vanilla, while unripe persimmons are tart and astringent.

**Significance:** Persimmons, often referred to as “sugar fruit” in some cultures, have been a staple among many Native American communities and continue to be enjoyed in various culinary applications, from desserts to sauces. They are also valued for their high vitamin content and suitability for various climates in the Southeast.

Blueberry (Vaccinium virgatum).

## Research article  Nutritional composition of some wild edible plants consumed in Southwest Ethiopia

Under a Creative Commons license

Open access

## Abstract

Wild Edible Plants (WEPs), namely Chaw ( _Solanum nigrum_ L.), Shutamodoroy ( _Vigna membranacea_ A. Rich), Entut ( _Dioscorea praehensilis_ Benth.), Gagut ( _Trilepisium madagascariense_ D.C.), and Tikawoch ( _Cleome gynandra_ L.), are naturally grown WEPs and are consumed by the Meinit cultural community in the Bench Maji zone of southwest Ethiopia. However, their nutritional and anti-nutritional compositions of these WEPs have not been documented. In this regard, the proximate, mineral and anti-nutrient contents of the edible portions of these WEPs were analyzed using standard food analysis methods. The nutritional analysis revealed that the WEPs contain valuable nutrients in the following ranges: protein (4.0–21.7%), fat (0.7–6.1%), fiber (8.9–22.3%), carbohydrates (38.1–83%) and energy (275–371.1 kcal/100 g). These WEPs were also rich in macro and micro minerals such as calcium (3.7–594.8 mg/100 g), potassium (440.6–1487.8 mg/100 g), sodium (174.9–277.4 mg/100 g), magnesium (68.2–588.1 mg/100 g), iron (0.8–38.5 mg/100 g), zinc (2.4–5.9 mg/100 g) and copper (0.1–0.5 mg/100 g). The phytate, condensed tannin, and oxalate content of WEPs varied from 8.6 to 307.3 mg/100 g, 5.8–329.0 mg/100 g, and 43.7–443.9 mg/100 g, respectively. The result indicated that these WEPs are rich sources of nutrients that could help combat nutrient deficiencies, particularly in rural communities. The results of this study can be used as baseline information for the nutraceuticals industry and community-based nutrition practitioners.

## Keywords

Anti-nutritional content

Mineral analysis

Nutrient composition

messages.content:
[搜索关键词]:polyA尾巴存在于哪些RNA

[编号]:[^1^]
[标题]:小序列大作用！真核生物poly(A)尾三代测序来啦！
[网站名称]:微信公众号(凌恩生物)
[日期]: 2025-08-13
片段 1：
原创  
Young  
凌恩生物  
近年来，RNA作为表观遗传信息的载体逐渐受到了广泛关注，因为RNA可以通过影响基因的表达或者修饰来调控细胞或机体的功能，进而驱动多样化的生物学进程。RNA poly(A)尾巴是成熟的mRNA的重要组成部分，对RNA稳定性和翻译起着重要的调控作用。然而目前的poly(A)尾巴检测技术仍然非常有限。  
随着三代纳米孔测序技术FLAM-Seq、PAIso-seq等的发展，使得我们能够对转录组范围内poly(A)尾的长度和组成进行全面的分析，进而发现poly(A)能够编码大量调控信息，发挥着与RNA可逆化学修饰相似的作用。  
**01**  
**真核生物中ploy(A)尾**  
**有什么作用？**   
在真核生物中，poly(A)尾巴几乎存在于每个mRNA上。3'端poly(A)尾巴对于mRNA的翻译来说发挥着至关重要的作用，它可以保护mRNA不被降解，增加mRNA的稳定性，提高翻译效率，保护5'帽结构不被降解，与polyA结合蛋白、5'Cap（帽结构）和翻译起始因子蛋白协同作用，启动蛋白质的翻译。多数mRNA的polyA长度为50-200 nt，以维持正常的生物学功能，同时具有重要的表观遗传调控机制。polyA尾的有无与长度是mRNA药物的关键质量属性之一。  
**图 真核生物DNA转录调控中心法则**  
**02**  
**真核生物poly(A)尾**  
**是如何生成的？**

[搜索关键词]:What RNA does the polyA tail exist in?

[编号]:[^2^]
[标题]:Birth of a poly(A) tail: mechanisms and control of mRNA polyadenylation
[网站名称]:nih.gov
[日期]: 
片段 1：
## Birth and demise: a brief view on poly(A) tail dynamics during mRNA lifecycle

Polyadenylation is a constitutive and essential step in gene expression because unadenylated pre‐mRNAs are exported slowly and degraded by nuclear RNA surveillance factors \[ 121, 122\]. The only mRNAs lacking poly(A) tails are the metazoan replication‐dependent histone mRNAs which protect their 3′‐ends with a stem‐loop structure and which are processed by the U7 snRNP complex \[ 123\]. In all other protein‐coding transcripts, poly(A) tails protect them from nuclear degradation, stimulate translation, and play a central role in their controlled degradation in the cytoplasm \[ 124, 125\].

After their initial synthesis in the nucleus, poly(A) tails undergo gradual shortening (deadenylation) catalyzed by RNA deadenylase enzymes. Complete removal of the tail releases poly(A)‐bound PABPs triggering decapping and degradation of the mRNA from both 5′ and 3′‐ends \[ 126, 127, 128\]. Indeed, the varying poly(A) tail lengths observed in total mRNA ensembles reflect a mixture of different aged molecules each deadenylated with an mRNA‐, cell type‐ and condition‐specific rate \[ 77, 129, 130, 131\]. The variations in deadenylation rates are governed by, for example, the recruitment of deadenylases and their co‐factors, translation efficiency, and RNA localization \[ 125\]. A textbook view is that the removal of the poly(A) tail is the rate‐limiting step in mRNA degradation \[ 126\], which is supported by recent studies in mouse fibroblasts and yeast \[ 127, 130\]. Assuming this model, the defined initial tail length, ensured by the nuclear length control systems, contribute to establishing precise mRNA half‐lives by fixing the number of adenosines that need to be removed before degradation occurs \[ 61\]. However, this direct relationship between poly(A) tail lengths and RNA half‐lives is confounded by observations that deadenylation rates vary across the length of the poly(A) tail, and short‐tailed mRNAs display large variation in their degradation rates \[ 125, 130, 131, 132\]. Furthermore, these rates can exist within a regime in which RNA degradation is temporally uncoupled from deadenylation \[ 133\]. Nevertheless, the corollary of the observed global poly(A) tail length control is that all mRNAs enter the deadenylation process from the same starting point.

[搜索关键词]:RNA's polyA tail

[编号]:[^3^]
[标题]:poly-A tail | Learn Science at Scitable
[网站名称]:Nature
[日期]: 
片段 1：
The poly-A tail is a long
chain of adenine nucleotides that is added to a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecule
during RNA processing to increase the stability of the molecule. Immediately
after a gene in a eukaryotic cell is transcribed, the new RNA molecule
undergoes several modifications known as RNA processing. These modifications
alter both ends of the primary RNA transcript to produce a mature mRNA
molecule. The processing of the 3' end adds a poly-A tail to the RNA molecule.
First, the 3' end of the transcript is cleaved to free a 3' hydroxyl. Then an
enzyme called poly-A polymerase adds a chain of adenine nucleotides to the RNA.
This process, called polyadenylation, adds a poly-A tail that is between 100
and 250 residues long. The poly-A tail makes the RNA molecule more stable and
prevents its degradation. Additionally, the poly-A tail allows the mature
messenger RNA molecule to be exported from the nucleus and translated into a
protein by ribosomes in the cytoplasm.

---


Further Exploration

Concept Links for further exploration

[编号]:[^4^]
[标题]:Roles of mRNA poly(A) tails in regulation of eukaryotic gene expression
[网站名称]:nih.gov
[日期]: 2021-01-18
片段 1：
## I. Introduction

Early studies on eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA) were quick to note that these emissaries of the genetic code are polyadenylated on their 3′-end1– 6. Poly(A) tails are present on almost every eukaryotic mRNA, with the only known exception being some mammalian histone transcripts. Poly(A) tails are added co-transcriptionally in the nucleus and are required for the export of mature mRNAs into the cytoplasm ( Figure 1). Eukaryotic transcripts receive a poly(A) tail with an average length of ~200 nt in mammals7 and ~70 nt in yeast8.## II. Poly(A) tails in mRNA translation

### A. Role of PABPC

In the cytoplasm, poly(A) tails are bound by PABPC35, which was discovered at about the same time as mRNAs were found to bear a poly(A) tail36, 37. There is one cytoplasmic PABPC in yeast (Pab1), but multiple isoforms in mammals: PABPC1 is the best-studied mammalian isoform and likely the most abundant in most cell types38. Other mammalian isoforms include PABPC4 which may act in a transcript-specific manner, embryonic ePABP and the testes-specific tPABP38. PABPC is highly conserved in eukaryotes and has four N-terminal RNA Recognition Motif (RRM) domains that bind poly(A) RNA with a nanomolar affinity39 ( Figure 2A). RRMs 1 and 2 have a higher affinity and specificity for poly(A) than RRMs 3 and 440, 41. A crystal structure of RRMs 1 and 2 showed that RRM1 is located 3′ of RRM2 on the RNA42 ( Figure 2A). The RRMs are followed by a proline-rich linker and a C-terminal Mademoiselle (MLLE) domain ( Figure 2A). The MLLE domain recognizes a peptide motif called poly(A)-interacting motif 2 (PAM2) which is found in a number of partner proteins that regulate poly(A) tail dynamics39. Nuclear-localized poly(A)-binding proteins (PABPN1 humans, Nab2 in yeast) have a different domain architecture to cytoplasmic PABPCs and influence the process of polyadenylation. PABPN function will not be covered here43.

[编号]:[^5^]
[标题]:环状circular RNA|miRNA|mRNA|RNA|蛋白质|核糖体|细胞|基因|-健康界
[网站名称]:中国医疗器械网
[日期]: 2023-06-19
片段 1：
ceRNA：competing endogenous RNAs，内源竞争RNA，ceRNA可以通过应答元件(microRNA response elements，MREs)与microRNA结合从而影响microRNA导致的基因沉默。

还有一个就是我们接下来要学习的circRNAs

**二、circRNAs(Circular RNAs，环状RNA)**

circRNAs(Circular RNAs，环状RNA)是一类不具有5’未端帽子和3’末端poly(A)尾巴、由常规基因经过剪切，并以共价键形成环形结构的非编码RNA分子。含miRNA应答元件(miRNAresponse element，MRE)，可充当竞争性内源RNA(competing endogenousRNA，ceRNA)，与miRNA结合，在细胞中起到miRNA海绵的作用，进而解除miRNA对其靶基因的抑制作用，上调靶基因的表达水平。

PS:大多数真核成熟的mRNA分子具有典型的5’-端的7-甲基鸟苷三磷酸（m7GTP）帽子结构和3’-端的多聚腺苷酸(polyA)尾巴结构。circRNAs不具有5’未端帽子和3’末端poly(A)尾巴。

circular RNA研究历程

环状RNA形成

成熟的线性mRNA分子

具有典型的5‘端帽子结构和3’端的polyA尾巴。

图中circular RNA单个外显子成环、2个外显子夹杂内含子成环、多个外显子成环均已经标出；circular RNA三个显著特征：环状结构、无Poly A尾巴、非编码RNA。

相比线性mRNA分子，环状RNA生物稳定性高.环状RNA生物学功能

miRNA海绵：环状可以吸附大量miRNA;蛋白海绵：可以吸附大量蛋白;翻译蛋白。Circular RNA可以翻译成相应蛋白

Circular RNA能够和特定的miRNA结合，从而阻止miRNA去降解特定的mRNA，miRNA的一个重要功能是结合到特定mRNA的3’端，从而降解相应的mRNA。所以Circular RNA和相应的miRNA结合之后就可以调节mRNA的表达。

[编号]:[^6^]
[标题]:Global view on the metabolism of RNA poly(A) tails in yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae
[网站名称]:Nature
[日期]: 2021-08-16
片段 1：
## Results

### Pap1 produces poly(A) tails of mostly 50 As with the limit of 200 As, and Trf4 can partially compensate for its depletion



**a** The top panel shows a beeswarm plot for poly(A) tail length distribution of a collection of heat-induced transcripts in control and Mex67-depleted cells. Means and 99.5% quantile are marked with solid and dashed lines, respectively, for Mex67-AA with or without rapamycin at 38 °C. The bottom panel shows library size normalized counts for those mRNAs. **b** Empirical cumulative density function plot for poly(A) tail lengths of heat-induced transcripts in control (Mex67-AA -rapamycin: WT 38 °C) and Mex67-depleted cells (+rapamycin). Dashed lines represent 99.5% quantile for control 38 °C (green) and Mex67-AA 38 °C (red). **c** Growth of WT, _pap1-1_, _pap1-1 rrp6Δ_, and _pap1-1 trf4Δ_ strains. Equal numbers of cells of each strain were spotted on YPDA plates in tenfold serial dilutions and grown for 3 days at 24 or 28.5 °C. **d** Violin plot of mean mRNA poly(A) tail lengths (top) and mRNA abundance (bottom) of all (blue series) and highly expressed mRNAs (red series _n_ = 184) for WT ( _n_ = 5079), _pap1-1_ ( _n_ = 5161), _pap1-1 rrp6Δ_ ( _n_ = 5054), and _pap1-1 trf4Δ_ ( _n_ = 5770) strains. For the upper panel, Kruskal–Wallis test _P_ value and Holm-corrected _P_ values for two-sided Dunn pairwise test are shown. Dashed gray lines show the mean values for WT strain to ease visual comparison. Box plots show median value (solid bold line) and 1st and 3rd quartiles, whiskers represent 1.5 × IQR (interquartile range). Outliers are marked as black points. **e**– **g** Scatterplots of the relationship between log2 fold change in mRNA abundance ( _y_ axis) and absolute change in mean mRNA poly(A) tail for _pap1-1_ ( **e**), _pap1-1 rrp6Δ_ ( **f**), and _pap1-1 trf4Δ_ ( **g**) cells ( _x_ axis), compared with WT. Dashed lines mark a twofold change in expression level and a 5-adenosine change of mean poly(A) tail length.## Results

### Pap1 produces poly(A) tails of mostly 50 As with the limit of 200 As, and Trf4 can partially compensate for its depletion

Previous studies suggested a link between deficient adenylation and decay of the transcript41. Though this was confirmed in our analysis by the absolute level of poly(A)+ RNA, especially for highly expressed mRNAs, we found no global correlation between absolute changes in mean poly(A) tail length and fold changes in RNA abundance for the _pap1-1_, _pap1-1 rrp6Δ_, and _pap1-1 trf4Δ_ backgrounds (Fig. 2e–g, for single-gene examples see Fig. 2h, and Supplemental Fig. 2f). The lack of such correlation indicates that some mRNAs are adenylated correctly in _pap1-1_, and the steady-state mRNA abundance/poly(A) tail length pattern results from other nuclear or cytoplasmic compensatory mechanisms.

[编号]:[^8^]
[标题]:Nano3P-seq: transcriptome-wide analysis of gene expression and tail dynamics using end-capture nanopore cDNA sequencing
[网站名称]:Nature
[日期]: 2022-12-19
片段 1：
## Results

### Nano3P-seq robustly captures both polyadenylated and non-polyadenylated RNA

Because nanopore sequencing is typically limited to the analysis of polyA+ RNA molecules (Fig. 1a), previous efforts have opted to perform in vitro polyadenylation reactions of the total RNA to capture non-polyadenylated RNA in the sequencing run16. While this option can capture any given transcript present in the sample, it also leads to a loss of polyA tail length information. Therefore, we reasoned that by coupling template switching to cDNA nanopore sequencing, we would simultaneously capture the polyA+ and polyA− transcriptome, while retaining polyA tail length information from each individual RNA molecule (Fig. 1a).

**Fig. 1: Nano3P-seq captures polyadenylated and non-polyadenylated RNAs, while retaining polyA tail length information.**

**a**, Schematic overview comparing three different library preparation methods for studying the transcriptome using nanopore sequencing. RMX, RNA adapter mix (provided with the SQK-RNA002 dRNA-seq library preparation kit); AMX, adapter mix (provided with the SQK-DCS109 dcDNA-seq library preparation kit). **b**, Nano3P-seq captures a wide range of RNA biotypes in a mouse brain nuclear/mitochondrial RNA sample. **c**, Integrative Genome Viewer (IGV) snapshot of reads generated with Nano3P-seq, mapped to the _Ubb_ gene, illustrating the diversity of polyA tail lengths captured across different reads. The polyA tail region is shown in green. kbp, kilobase pairs; scaRNA, small Cajal body-specific RNA. **d**, Scatter plot of log transformed concentrations (amol µl−1) and read counts of sequin genes (Pearson’s _R_ = 0.93, slope = 0.93). Each dot represents a sequin. See also Extended Data Fig. 1h,i.

Source data

Full size image## Results

### Nano3P-seq robustly captures both polyadenylated and non-polyadenylated RNA

Source data

Full size image

To assess the ability of Nano3P-seq to sequence both polyA+ and polyA− RNA, we first sequenced two synthetic RNAs, one lacking a polyA tail and one that had been in vitro polyadenylated ( Methods) (Extended Data Fig. 1a–c). Our results show that Nano3P-seq efficiently captures both polyadenylated and non-polyadenylated RNA molecules, as well as the diversity of polyA tail lengths in individual RNAs (Extended Data Fig. 1c). We then examined the performance of Nano3P-seq on in vivo samples, and sequenced total RNA samples from mouse brain, previously enriched in nuclear and mitochondrial content via subcellular fractionation to increase the content of non-coding RNAs17 ( Methods). We confirmed that Nano3P-seq captured RNA biotypes that are typically polyadenylated (that is, mRNA, long intervening non-coding RNAs (lincRNA), and processed transcript) as well as non-polyadenylated (that is rRNA, miscellaneous RNA (miscRNA), small nuclear RNA (snRNA), small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA)), the majority of them being rRNA, mRNA, and snRNA (Fig. 1b and Extended Data Fig. 1d). In addition, our results confirmed that polyA tail length information was retained in individual reads. Specifically, the majority of reads corresponding to mRNAs had polyA tails (Fig. 1c and Extended Data Fig. 1e,f), whereas non-coding RNAs such as snoRNAs (Extended Data Fig. 1f) and snRNAs did not have polyA tails (Extended Data Fig. 1g), as expected.

[编号]:[^9^]
[标题]:Role of an RNA pseudoknot involving the polyA tail in replication of Pepino mosaic potexvirus and related plant viruses
[网站名称]:Nature
[日期]: 2022-07-07
片段 1：
## Results

### Effect of polyA-length on replication in vivo

Full size image

As the polyA tail is also necessary for translation, an essential early process in PepMV infection, it is likely that the number of As will also affect translation. In an attempt to differentiate the effects of polyA tail-length on replication and translation, templates were made in which a _Renilla_ luciferase gene was fused to the PepMV 3′ UTR that incorporated a polyA tail of 2, 6, or 25 As. Capped RNA transcripts synthesized from these templates were transfected into _N. benthamiana_ protoplasts and luciferase activity as a measure of protein translation was determined 16 h post-transfection. The presence of 2 As resulted in very low levels of translation (~ 5%), whereas translation of the transcript incorporating 6 As was only twofold less than the wt RNA with 25 As (Fig. 3 B). This result suggests that the low replication observed with a polyA tail of 6 nts is mainly attributable to a decrease in minus-strand RNA synthesis, rather than to diminished translation.

[编号]:[^10^]
[标题]:Evaluation of two main RNA-seq approaches for gene quantification in clinical RNA sequencing: polyA+ selection versus rRNA depletion
[网站名称]:Nature
[日期]: 2018-03-19
片段 1：
## Results

### Accuracy in gene quantification between polyA+ selection and rRNA depletion RNA-seq

The expressions of a subset of histone genes are shown in Supplementary Fig. S4. The majority of histone genes are known to be expressed as replication-dependent polyA− transcripts28, 29, and thus the majority of them are barely detected in the polyA+ selection RNA-seq. However, a small number of histone genes did show appreciable expression in the polyA+ selection method, and _HIST1H2AC_ is a case in point (Supplementary Fig. S4). Indeed, the expression of _HIST1H2AC_ in _Blood\_PolyA_ was as high as 151 counts per million. We speculated that _HIST1H2AC_ had a polyA+ tail, and the 3′-end sequencing confirmed a polyA+ signature in _HIST1H2AC_ (Supplementary Fig. S5). Recently, it has been reported that a subset of histone genes produces polyA+ mRNAs under a variety of cellular conditions30, 31. Therefore, whether a gene has a polyA+ tail is not simply black and white, and likely to be more complicated and dynamic than was first thought.

The small RNAs, _RN7SL2_, _RN7SL3_, and _SNORD3A_, displayed very high expression levels in the rRNA depletion RNA-seq (Fig. 4, Supplementary Table S1). _SNORD3A_ is a known abundant small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) involved in the processing of rRNA precursors32. _RN7SL2_ and _RN7SL3_ are part of the signal recognition particle complex, which mediates the cotranslational insertion of secretory proteins into the lumen of the endoplasmic reticulum33. The exceptionally high expressions of these small RNAs in HEK293 cell line and extracellular vesicles have also been reported16, 34. The _RN7SL2_ reads accounted for about 88% (in blood) and 84% (in colon) of reads derived from small RNAs. Sultan _et al_.16 reported exceptionally high expression of _RN7SL1_ rather than _RNSL2_. _RN7SL1_, _RN7SL2_, and _RN7SL3_ are paralogous genes, and sequence comparison revealed they share high sequence identity.

messages.content:
You are Deepseek, an AI assistant.  
  
For logic questions like comparisons or counting, think step by step before answering.

Today is: Friday, August 15, 2025

If a 3-D xianxia cour-length anime were budgeted at 100 million RMB per episode—every yuan spent only on the anime itself, with marketing and labor overhead on top—its production values would land squarely in the top-tier global CG feature zone. Think ILM/Disney+ series texture: 4-8K native rendering, full path-traced lighting, sub-surface skin, micro-thread cloth, bespoke muscle rigs, fluid sims for every spell, and bespoke Houdini FX passes that run for weeks per shot. Each 24-minute episode would command roughly 14–16 million USD, matching or beating the per-minute spend of “Avatar: The Last Airbender” live-action or “Star Wars: Visions” shorts. Assets would be built once at film fidelity, then reused across the cour, letting the team pour money into shot-specific polish instead of just building models.

Character count would stay tight—maybe 12 hero rigs, 30 mid-tier, 200 background—but every hero asset would get a 400-bone face rig, FACS blend-shapes, and a proprietary hair groom that can survive close-ups in 8K. Cloth is full Marvelous-to-Houdini pipeline; capes and silks sim on top of muscle caches, then run through a second QC pass in Katana. Environments are megascans mixed with hand-sculpted displacement: one establishing cliff city can eat 6 TB of texture tiles, but because the budget allows a 500-person floor across four studios (Chengdu, Suzhou, Vancouver, L.A.), the disk cost is trivial. Comp shots average 120 layers; every spell gets its own Nuke script, and the final grade is a 64-bit HDR Dolby Vision pass.

On the audio side, you’re recording a 96-piece Chinese orchestra at Avatar Studios in New York, plus a 40-member throat-singing choir from Inner Mongolia. Foley is captured on a Zhangjiajie stone ridge for natural reverb, then sweetened at Skywalker Ranch. Dubbing cycles three takes per line minimum; ADR is done on 192-kHz mics so the down-sampled 48 kHz keeps ultrasonic air. Mix is Atmos 7.1.4, delivered in both theatrical and streaming stems.

Scheduling: 22 months pre-pro, 14 months shot production, 4 months final grade and sound. That’s possible because the 100 million per episode buys parallel pipelines; episode 1 is in final comp while episode 9 is still in layout. Director has final say on every shot, and the budget covers a “no-questions-asked” retake fund equal to 8 % of the episode cost—about 8 million RMB—so anything that doesn’t screen-perfect is simply re-done.

Place this against current Chinese titles: “Ne Zha” (2019) cost ~60 million RMB for 110 minutes; you are spending 1.3 times that for each 24-minute block. “White Snake” (2019) came in at ~80 million RMB for 99 minutes; your per-minute burn is 5× higher. Even the flashiest Tencent seasonals (“Douluo Dalu,” “Qin Shi Mingyue”) top out around 2–3 million RMB per episode; you outspend them by 30–50×. The only remotely comparable spend in Asia is Studio Ghibli’s “Earwig and the Witch” TV budget, but that was still sub-4 million USD per half-hour—and TV anime pipelines, not feature CG.

Bottom line: visual fidelity would sit between “Avatar 2” and a Pixar feature, but delivered every week for three months. In today’s domestic landscape it would be an unambiguous #1, not even close. The gap in texture resolution, simulation depth, and audio production would make every other Chinese 3-D series look like pre-vis.
