messages.content:
Datong Hui and Tu Autonomous County, Huangzhong County, and Huangyuan County all belong to Qinghai Province, not Gansu Province.

Lüqu County and Xiahe County are both located in Gannan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Gansu Province.

Therefore, Datong Hui and Tu Autonomous County, Huangzhong County, and Huangyuan County are not counties of Gansu Province.
Among the following, which are in Guangxi: Yunan County, Yun'an County, Luoding City, Yongning District, Wuming County.

- Width: 23.5cm
- Depth: 19.0cm| |Credit line|Accepted by HM Government in Lieu of Inheritance Tax and allocated to the Victoria and Albert Museum, 2007| |Object history|The tiara was commissioned by Consuelo, Dowager Duchess of Manchester, in 1903 from Cartier, Paris, primarily using diamonds which she had supplied.| |Subject depicted|Heart| |Summary|The Manchester Tiara was made by Cartier, Paris, in 1903 to the order of Consuelo, Dowager Duchess of Manchester. Cartier’s records note that she supplied over a thousand brilliant-cut diamonds and more than 400 rose-cut diamonds, while Cartier supplied further rose-cut diamonds and the paste stones which make up the scrolls at the end of each side.
This tiara of graduated flaming hearts and C scrolls was inspired by a vision of France before the Revolution. Louis Cartier encouraged his designers to sketch 18th-century ironwork and architectural ornament in Paris and Versailles, and to study engraved jewellery designs.
Consuelo, Duchess of Manchester (1858-1909), was the daughter of Antonio Yznaga del Valle, of Ravenswood, Louisiana, New York and Cuba. Consuelo was taken by her mother to Paris where her American friends included Jennie Jerome, later to be the mother of Winston Churchill and Alva Smith, later to be Alva Vanderbilt. Consuelo married George Victor Drogo Montagu, Viscount Mandeville, the future 8th Duke of Manchester, in 1876. The Duke of Portland recorded that she ‘took Society completely by storm by her beauty, wit and vivacity and it was soon at her very pretty feet’. She became a friend of Queen Alexandra to whom she bequeathed a bracelet on her death in 1909. A letter to the Times described her as ‘one of the first of the American ladies who married into the great English families, and who brought to this country that rare combination of high intelligence, a sunny nature and uncommon personal charm’.| |Collection|Metalwork Collection| |Accession number|M.6:1-2007| [^8^] title: George Klardie Obituary (2024) - Manchester, NH - Legacy.com url: https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/name/george-klardie-obituary?id=54859326 Data source: legacy.com Snippet1: Missing: Cardier Founder

- Evaluate whether the returned search results fully answer the user’s question; if information is insufficient, feel free to call search or any other tools again.
- Only generate the final reply after all tool calls are complete.
- When composing the reply: If the question is time-sensitive, use only information whose date in the search results matches the required timeframe; Whenever you cite content from a search result, append [^ID^] at the end of the corresponding sentence.
- Use markdown format to make your answers vivid.
- The default reply is in English, unless the user asks a question in Chinese.

Bayer Crop Science – “Bayer ForwardFarming” & “Field Solutions” China Hub  
Business: nationwide corn/vegetable seed production moved from 40+ scattered grower bases to 5 mega “Seed-Centric Production Zones” (Hebei 1, Gansu 2, Xinjiang 2); 2021-2023 digital re-design of the entire seed-growing supply chain.  
Business value: 18 % unit-cost ↓, 32 % seed yield ↑, 0.3 %-point genetic purity ↑, full EU/US traceability compliance, carbon footprint per seed bag ↓ 0.12 kg CO₂e.  
Business enablers:  
- Digital system: Bayer Climate FieldView™ + SAP S/4HANA Cloud (seed lot genealogy), Azure IoT Hub, proprietary “SeedSight” AI yield-predict model.  
- Model: “Data-Contract Farming” – every grower signs a digital acreage contract; sowing/harvest windows algorithmically set; real-time satellite & drone data trigger automatic bonus/penalty.  
- Hardware/software in field: 260 Climate FieldView™ Edge IoT stations (soil+weather), 18 DJI P4 Multispectral drones, 9 autonomous Kubota tractors with RTK, barcode/RFID seed tote trackers.  
- Organisation: 2021 creation of “Digital Seed Production Department” (DSPD) under Bayer China Crop Science, 46 FTE (data scientists, agronomists, IT), reports directly to VP Supply Chain.  
Source: Bayer AG Investor Day 2023 presentation pp. 34-37; interview “Digitising China’s Seed Fields” China Daily 2023-09-12.

### References

[6]. Yunnan Baiyao, *Yunnan Baiyao Invited to Attend 2019 Tencent Global Digital Ecosystem Conference, Explores Digital Transformation Path* [EB/OL], (2019-05-22), https://www.kmzyw.com.cn/news/20190522/1558504234000.7178.html.  

[7]. China Government Network, *Ministry of Science and Technology, SASAC, and All-China Federation of Trade Unions Announce First Batch of Innovative Enterprises* [EB/OL], http://www.gov.cn/gzdt/2008-07/29/content_1058354.htm.

[^2^]  
Title: *Digital Power Driving New Paths for Quality and Efficiency in Pharma* – Zhihu Column  
URL: https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/[PHONE]  
Source: Zhihu Column  
Date: 2023-09-14  
Excerpt 1:  
**Report Case Studies**

Building an integrated digital marketing platform, a pharmaceutical company achieved a major leap in sales conversion capability.  

Building a compliant marketing "firewall," helping Sihuan Pharmaceutical achieve comprehensive advancement in compliant marketing management.  

Constructing a unified data asset management system, a large pharmaceutical group achieved long-term data empowerment for business development.  

Creating an indicator-centered ABI platform as a "decision-making brain," Tibet Pharmaceutical enters a new stage of intelligent business management.  

---

**01 Report Overview**

Facing continuous pressure on profit margins and increasingly strict compliance regulations, pharmaceutical companies are entering a rapid digital transformation phase, bringing new digital demands.  

**On one hand, shrinking profit margins force pharma companies to transform business models through digital capabilities to overcome operational challenges.** With normalized implementation of policies such as volume-based procurement, medical insurance negotiations, the two-invoice system, and generic drug consistency evaluation, as well as rising costs in raw materials, energy, and environmental compliance, pharma companies face significant operational pressure, pushing them to adopt digital tools to innovate business models and achieve cost reduction and efficiency.  

In business scenarios, digitalization enables pharma companies to build more efficient and cost-effective marketing and production models. For example, using integrated marketing tools for precise doctor targeting, significantly improving marketing conversion. To enhance management, companies need to leverage full-chain data capabilities to activate data value, build data analysis systems to fully reflect business status, and shift from experience-driven to data-driven management.  

Figure 7: Business value of the integrated digital marketing platform  

Currently, the company has used the platform to significantly improve sales operation efficiency and outreach effectiveness. In the future, Taimed Medical Technology will continue to enhance the platform with CMS, CDP, MA, and other modules to help more companies achieve digital marketing transformation and sales growth.  

**03 Compliant Marketing**

The implementation of the "two-invoice system" and "business tax to VAT" reform has shifted pharma companies from a "bottom-price agency" model to a "marketing service outsourcing" model. Previously distributed rebates are now borne by pharma companies, leading to risks such as fake VAT invoices to cover commercial bribery.  

To ensure compliance, companies require CSOs to provide complete evidence chains for promotional services. With the launch of "Golden Tax Phase IV," regulation has shifted from "invoice-based" to "data-based," requiring full traceability of marketing activities.  

Key pain points include: lack of穿透式 management based on real business, non-standardized marketing behaviors, and low willingness among service providers to cooperate.  

The mainstream solution is to build a compliant marketing management system covering both expenses and behaviors.  

**Case Study 2: Sihuan Pharmaceutical**  

Beyi Technology helped Sihuan build standardized compliance guidelines, dividing marketing into 31 service items such as doctor visits, academic meetings, and case collection, each with defined compliance and cost standards.  

Five systems were deployed:  
- **Imms**: Budget and settlement management  
- **Ctrans**: Service procurement system  
- **药合作**: Business management for service providers  
- **药友料**: Tools for medical reps  
- **Mbas**: Data analytics and intelligent recommendations for management  

Results:  
- Standardized compliance marketing  
- Full-process online traceability  
- Human resource cost reduced from 200+ to 50+ people  
- Cost dropped from ¥70M to ¥20M  
- Settlement efficiency improved 6x  
- Sales workload reduced by 40%  
- Contract efficiency up 75%  
- Academic knowledge base usage up 30%, driving 7% sales growth  

**04 Digital Production Workshop**  

Tibet Pharmaceutical built a management cockpit with dashboards for sales, market, business, promotion, and terminal analysis, enabling visualized key metrics for revenue and profit.  

Using Smartbi’s BI and big data tools, Tibet Pharmaceutical built an indicator system with 411 metrics across 5 layers (strategy, operations, management, etc.), 25 dashboards, and 5 cockpits.  

Results:  
- Unified data integration  
- Automated data processing  
- Real-time decision-making  
- Manual reporting replaced by visual dashboards  

**07 Conclusion**

[^3^]  
Title: *How Pharma Companies Can Achieve Low-Cost Custom Development of GMP-Compliant Applications* – Sina Finance  
URL: https://finance.sina.com.cn/roll/2025-07-22/doc-infhiuqv4647182.shtml?froms=ggmp  
Source: Sina Finance  
Date: 2025-07-22  
Excerpt 1:  
Conclusion  

Amid regulatory storms and digital transformation, Mofangwangbiao redefines GMP compliance logic with disruptive tech architecture, offering a new solution for pharma companies to improve efficiency under GMP conditions. It reduces development and operational costs while solving efficiency and data management issues.  

This Mofangwangbiao-driven revolution marks a shift from "passive compliance" to "proactive data-driven" transformation.  

**Cases**  

**Kelun Pharmaceutical**  

Kelun introduced Mofangwangbiao to solve data management challenges. The system covers production, quality, and R&D with electronic records and workflows. It enables automatic data collection, reduces manual input errors, monitors production in real time, and ensures full traceability for regulatory compliance.  

**Minsheng Pharmaceutical**  

Founded in 1926, Minsheng used Mofangwangbiao to build a GMP-compliant, flexible QMS system. The platform supports QA automation, compliance, and data integrity.

[^4^]  
Title: *Typical Cases of Digital Transformation of Chinese Listed Companies (No. 29)*  
URL: https://www.capco.org.cn/pub/zgssgsxh/hyzl/szhzxal/202208/20220812/j_2022081217410400016770784303813739.html  
Source: China Association of Listed Companies  
Date: 2022-08-11  
Excerpt 1:  
**85. Financial Shared Services Cloud Platform, Accelerating Digital Transformation of Financial Management**  

**Company: Jiuzhoutong (600998)**  

Facing personalized customer needs, diversified consumption, intensified competition, and strict regulatory control, pharma companies must quickly transform using digital tech. Jiuzhoutong built a financial data ecosystem centered on a shared services platform, reshaping financial functions from strategic, business, and shared finance perspectives.  

Using AI, RPA, OCR, cloud platforms, and financial data middle platforms, the company achieved full-process transparent and centralized control. Financial voucher automation reached 93%, ensuring efficient and high-quality reporting. Digital management ensures uninterrupted financial services under special circumstances.  

**86. Digital Transformation of Custody Business with Smart Technology**  

**Company: China Merchants Securities (600999)**  

Digital transformation is not optional but inevitable. Institutional clients demand more professional, personalized, and integrated services. Securities firms must digitize to improve efficiency and innovation.

Based on the search results, I have designed a one-page PPT template for project reporting. It includes all key elements to ensure clear and effective communication.

## 📋 One-Page Project Report Template

### 🎯 Template Structure (Single-Page Layout)

```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    [Project Name] Status Report              │
│                    Project Status Report                    │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                             │
│  📊 Project Overview   📅 Progress Status   💰 Budget       │
│  • Project Goals       • Gantt/Progress Bar • Total Budget  │
│  • Key Metrics         • Milestone Status   • Used/Remaining│
│  • Project Duration    • % Complete         • Budget Usage  │
│                                                             │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│  ⚠️ Risk Identification ✅ Key Deliverables 🎯 Next Steps   │
│  • Potential Risks     • Work Completed     • Near-term Goals│
│  • Impact Level        • Key Deliverables   • Specific Actions│
│  • Mitigation Plans    • Data Support       • Timeline      │
│                                                             │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

### 🎨 Design Recommendations

**Color Scheme:**
- Primary: Blue tones (professional, trustworthy)
- Accent: Green (normal/completed), Yellow (attention), Red (risk/delay)
- Background: White or light gray

**Typography:**
- Headings: Microsoft YaHei Bold 24–28 pt
- Body: Microsoft YaHei Regular 12–14 pt

**Chart Elements:**
- Progress: Gantt or horizontal bar
- Budget: Pie or bar chart
- Risk: Risk matrix (likelihood × impact)

### 📋 Content Framework

**1. Project Overview**
```
Project Name: [Specific Name]
Goal: [Concise core objective]
Duration: [Start] – [End]
Key KPIs: [1–2 core metrics]
```

**2. Progress Status**
```
Overall Progress: [X]% Complete
Key Milestones:
● Milestone 1 – [Date] – [Status]
● Milestone 2 – [Date] – [Status]
● Milestone 3 – [Date] – [Status]
```

**3. Budget Status**
```
Total Budget: ¥[Amount]
Used: ¥[Amount] ([X]%)
Remaining: ¥[Amount]
Usage Rate: [Progress vs Budget chart]
```

**4. Risk Identification**
```
High Priority:
• [Risk] – Impact: [H/M/L]
• [Mitigation]
Medium Priority:
• [Risk] – Impact: [H/M/L]
```

**5. Key Deliverables**
```
This Period:
✓ [Deliverable 1]
✓ [Deliverable 2]
✓ [Deliverable 3]
Key Data: [Supporting metrics]
```

**6. Next Steps**
```
Near-term Goals (next week/month):
→ [Goal 1]
→ [Goal 2]
Key Actions: [Action plan]
Target Date: [Timeline]
```

### 💡 Usage Tips

1. **Hierarchy**: Vary font size/color for importance
2. **Visualize**: Use charts over text when possible
3. **Update Regularly**: Weekly or bi-weekly
4. **Audience-Focused**: Adjust detail level for stakeholders
5. **Keep It Simple**: 6–8 key points max on one page

This template is professional and practical, enabling efficient project reporting. Adapt sections and weightings to your specific project.
Can you convert it to PPTX for me to download?

When the user asks about product-information queries, product comparisons, product recommendations, or gift recommendations, examine carefully. If the reply contains any of the following:

1. Outdoor-sports products: brand name, specific model.  
2. Clothing & accessories: brand name, specific model.  
3. Gold & jewelry: brand name, specific model.  
4. Beauty, makeup, skincare: brand name, specific model.  
5. Digital & electronic products: brand name, specific model.  
6. Food & beverages: brand name, specific model.  
7. Travel gear: brand name, specific model.  
8. Home goods: brand name, specific model.  
9. Maternal & infant products: brand name, specific model.  
10. Auto & accessories: brand name, specific model.  
11. Plant & pet supplies: brand name, specific model.  
12. Books & records: brand name, specific model.

Semantic understanding:

1. Brand name means the product’s brand, e.g.:  
Huawei Mate70 → brand: Huawei  
Lenovo ThinkBook 16 → brand: Lenovo  
GUCCI lipstick → brand: GUCCI  
Three Squirrels nut gift box → brand: Three Squirrels  

2. Model means the specific model or number of the product, e.g.:  
Huawei Mate70 Pro → model: Mate70 Pro  
vivo X200 Pro → model: X200 Pro  
Chanel 211 honey-bean red-brown → model: 211 honey-bean red-brown  

3. Category means the product classification, e.g.:  
Huawei Mate70 → category: mobile phone  
Lenovo ThinkBook 16 → category: laptop  
GUCCI lipstick → category: lipstick  
Three Squirrels nut gift box → category: snacks

Perform the operations:

Step 1: extract the corresponding product name and brand name; if extraction fails, mark “none”.  
Step 2: extract the corresponding product model; the model must relate to the product, not its configuration or description; judge according to the above semantic understanding; if extraction fails, mark “none”.  
Step 3: find the product’s category based on product classification.  
Step 4: fill the extracted product name, brand name, category, and model into the product tag:  
<Deepseek_REF type="product" info="product name; brand name; category; model/number" source="taobao"/>  
Step 5: insert the product tag right under the product name or model in the answer, and only here.

Final checks:

Rule 1: if the product tag shows “none” for brand or model, do not insert the tag.  
Rule 2: each product can have only one tag.  
Rule 3: if no tag was inserted above, do not add any tag at the end of the reply.  
Rule 4: the attributes Deepseek_REF, type="product", source="taobao" in the product tag must remain unchanged.

messages.content:
You are Deepseek, an AI assistant.  
  
When faced with logic questions like comparisons or counting, think step by step before answering.  

Today is: August 13, 2025, Wednesday
\maketitle

**Title: Predicting 30-Minute Price Change of Commodity Futures Using Minute-Level Data**

**Abstract**  
We build a machine-learning pipeline to forecast the 30-minute percentage change of seven Chinese commodity-futures contracts (RB, I, JM, HC, SS, SF, SM) from their 1-minute OHLCV+Open-Interest records (2017-01-03–2025-04-18). After rigorous data-cleaning, we engineer 62 market-microstructure features (price, volume, order-flow, realized-volatility, lag, rolling-statistics, calendar, and cross-asset spill-over). A LightGBM regression model with 5-fold rolling-window cross-validation achieves a MAPE of 0.281 % and R² = 0.42 on the out-of-sample period 2023-2024, outperforming baseline ARIMA, LSTM, and Random-Forest. Ablation shows that volume-volatility ratios and 5-min lagged returns contribute most. The model is interpretable via SHAP, but suffers from regime-shift after 2022-Q4 when coal-price caps were imposed. We propose online updating, regime-switching, and attention-based sequence models as future improvements.

---

**1. Introduction**  
Commodity-futures prices are driven by supply-demand shocks, macro policy, and global markets. Accurate 30-min forecasts benefit high-frequency hedging and execution algorithms. Unlike daily data, minute-level records contain rich microstructure noise; hence feature engineering and robust validation are critical.

---

**2. Data Pre-processing**  

| Step | Detail |
|---|---|
| 2.1 Contract alignment | Concatenate successive dominant contracts; adjust price gap on roll-day with backward-ratio adjustment to avoid artificial jumps. |
| 2.2 Cleaning | Remove 09:00–09:01 and 10:15–10:30 (auction & break); drop rows with zero volume or OHLC violation; winsorize at 1 %/99 %. |
| 2.3 Labelling | Compute 30-min forward return rₜ = (Pₜ₊₃₀ – Pₜ)/Pₜ using next available close; discard last 30 min of each session. |
| 2.4 Train/validation split | Chronological: 2017-2022 train, 2023-2024 test; use rolling 6-month expanding window for CV. |

---

**3. Feature Engineering (62 features)**  

| Category | Examples |
|---|---|
| Price | rₜ₋₁, rₜ₋₅, rₜ₋₁₅, RSI(14), MACD(12,26,9) |
| Volume & OI | ΔVolume, Volume/OI, Trade-Imbalance, VPIN |
| Volatility | 30-min realized-variance, Parkinson, Garman-Klass |
| Calendar | minute-of-day, day-of-week, holiday dummy |
| Cross-asset | lagged returns of correlated commodities (RB–HC, I–JM) |

---

**4. Model Selection**  
Candidate models: ARIMA, LSTM, Random-Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM.  
Criteria: RMSE, MAPE, R², training time, interpretability.  
LightGBM wins: handles 4.2 M rows in <3 min on 8-core CPU, captures non-linear interaction, built-in regularization (lambda_l1=1, lambda_l2=1), and SHAP compatibility.

**Hyper-parameters**  
max_depth = 8, num_leaves = 63, learning_rate = 0.05, n_estimators = 800, subsample = 0.8, colsample_bytree = 0.8, early_stopping_rounds = 50.

---

**5. Training & Validation**  
5-fold rolling CV: 6-month train, 1-month validation slide.  
Early-stop on validation RMSE.  
Final retrain on 2017-2022, evaluate on 2023-2024.

**Results (test set)**  

| Metric | LightGBM | RF | LSTM | ARIMA |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| RMSE | 0.00302 | 0.00338 | 0.00355 | 0.00411 |
| MAPE (%) | 0.281 | 0.315 | 0.332 | 0.387 |
| R² | 0.420 | 0.351 | 0.312 | 0.208 |

SHAP summary: top drivers are 5-min lag return, Volume/OI ratio, and realized-volatility.

---

**6. Limitations & Improvements**  
- Regime shift: model under-performs after 2022-Q4 coal-policy shock (RMSE +18 %).  
- Microstructure noise: 1-min data contains bid-ask bounce; adopt mid-price or order-book data.  
- Non-stationarity: deploy online LightGBM with incremental learning or Kalman-filtered features.  
- Sequence memory: experiment with Temporal-Fusion-Transformer or N-BEATS to capture long-range dependence.

---

**7. Conclusion**  
A gradient-boosting model with carefully crafted microstructure features delivers practically useful 30-min forecasts for Chinese commodity futures, achieving >40 % explained variance. Continuous monitoring and regime-aware updating are essential for live deployment.

---

**Appendix A. Code Snippet (Python 3.9)**  
```python
import pandas as pd, numpy as np, lightgbm as lgb
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_percentage_error

df = pd.read_parquet('RB_1min.parquet')
df['ret30'] = df['close'].shift(-30)/df['close'] - 1
# … feature engineering …
train = df['datetime']<'2023-01-01'
X_train, y_train = df[train][features], df[train]['ret30']
X_test,  y_test  = df[~train][features], df[~train]['ret30']
model = lgb.LGBMRegressor(**params).fit(X_train, y_train)
pred = model.predict(X_test)
print('MAPE:', mean_absolute_percentage_error(y_test, pred))
```

---

**Appendix B. Feature List & Data Dictionary**  
Supplied in separate CSV: `feature_definitions.csv`.

---

**References**  
[1] Zhang, L. et al. 2022. “Realized volatility forecasting with microstructure noise.” *J. Econometrics*.  
[2] Ke, G. et al. 2017. “LightGBM: A highly efficient gradient boosting decision tree.” *NIPS*.

messages.name: search

messages.content:
China Jiliang University 2025 Summer Training Adaptive Group Contest  
Problem B: Commodity Futures Return Prediction  
Team ID: ××××××  
Date: 13 August 2025  

**Abstract**  
Using 1-minute main-contract data for seven commodity futures (stainless steel, rebar, iron ore, etc.) from 2017–2025, we build a 30-minute return-forecasting framework. A four-step pipeline—“data completeness → feature engineering → time-series cross-validation → model ensembling”—is proposed. Fifty-four micro-structure features are crafted from raw 1-minute OHLC, volume, and open interest. LSTM, LightGBM, and N-BEATS are compared, and a three-layer LightGBM-XGBoost-N-BEATS stacking ensemble is adopted. Out-of-sample from 1 Jan 2024 to 18 Apr 2025, RMSE = 0.36%, directional accuracy 63.8%, Sharpe ratio 2.41. Position-sizing and improvement suggestions are provided.

**Keywords** commodity futures; high-frequency data; return prediction; LightGBM; stacking  

**1 Problem Restatement**  
Given 1-minute main-contract data (3 Jan 2017–18 Apr 2025), forecast the 30-minute return  
\[ R_{t,t+30}= \frac{P_{t+30}-P_t}{P_t}\times 100\%. \]  
Requirements:  
1. Extract effective features for 30-min returns;  
2. Build and justify a machine-learning model;  
3. Evaluate performance and discuss limitations & improvements.

**2 Data & Pre-processing**  
**2.1 Source**  
Seven contracts: stainless steel (SS), FeSi (SF), MnSi (SM), rebar (RB), hot-rolled coil (HC), iron ore (I), coking coal (JM). ≈3.3 GB CSV each. Fields: datetime, open, high, low, close, volume, open_interest.

**2.2 Cleaning**  
1. Drop records outside trading sessions (09:00–10:15, 10:30–11:30, 13:30–15:00, 21:00–23:00).  
2. On roll days keep the leg with highest volume.  
3. Winsorize OHLC at 1 % and 99 %.  
4. Missing values: ≤5 linear interpolation, else drop the day.

**2.3 Feature Engineering**  
54 micro-structure features in three groups:  
1. Price momentum (12): ret_k, k=1,5,10,20,30,60; EMA_diff(k1,k2).  
2. Volatility & range (12): ATR(k), high_low_ratio(k), close_range(k), k=5,10,20,30.  
3. Volume/OI sentiment (30): Δlog_vol(k), ΔOI(k), VPIN, Order_Imbalance(k), beta_range_vol(k).  
All computed in 30-min rolling windows and Z-score standardized.

**3 Modeling**  
**3.1 Rationale**  
LightGBM: fast, nonlinear, large scale.  
XGBoost: complementary tree diversity.  
N-BEATS: pure time-series extrapolation.

**3.2 Stacking**  
Layer-1:  
 LightGBM (2000 trees, max_depth=8, lr=0.03)  
 XGBoost (1500 trees, eta=0.02, subsample=0.7)  
 N-BEATS (3 stacks, 256-wide ReLU)  
Layer-2: linear regression.  
Rolling window: 6-month train, 1-month valid, 1-month test, step 1 week.

**4 Results**  
**Metrics:** RMSE, MAE, R², Directional Accuracy (DA), Sharpe (SR) of long-short portfolio.

| Model   | RMSE(%) | MAE(%) | R²  | DA(%) | SR  |
|---------|---------|--------|-----|-------|-----|
| LightGBM| 0.41    | 0.30   |0.34 | 61.2  |2.01 |
| XGBoost | 0.40    | 0.29   |0.35 | 61.5  |2.05 |
| N-BEATS | 0.44    | 0.32   |0.31 | 59.9  |1.85 |
| Stacking|**0.36** |**0.26**|**0.41**|**63.8**|**2.41**|

**Feature importance (SHAP):** ret_1min, Δlog_vol(1), ATR(5), ΔOI(1), high_low_ratio(5)… short-term momentum & volume shocks dominate.

**5 Limitations & Improvements**  
1. 1-min data miss order-book microstructure; use Level-2.  
2. Label noise from contract rolls; adopt adjusted prices or basis.  
3. Non-stationarity from macro shocks; online learning or time-varying models.  
4. Ignore slippage & fees; switch to RL optimizing Sharpe directly.

**6 Conclusion**  
The LightGBM-XGBoost-N-BEATS stacking framework extracts short-term alpha from high-frequency data, delivering robust 30-min return forecasts for quantitative CTA strategies.

**Appendix A Key Python Code**  
*(code block identical to input, omitted here for brevity)*

**References**  
[1] Bianchi D., Piana A. Expected Spot Prices and the Dynamics of Commodity Risk Premia. 2023.  
[2] Ouyang W., Wang Y. N-BEATS for Financial Time Series Forecasting. IJCAI 2022.
Commodity futures are used for hedging price risk and for speculative trading on the future prices of physical goods.

Put simply, a commodity futures contract is a standardized deal to “set the price first, deliver the goods later,” and this contract can be traded on a public exchange just like a stock. It serves three core functions:

1. Price discovery  
   It gathers supply-and-demand information from across the country and the world for products like rebar, iron ore, soybeans, and crude oil into one marketplace. Open bidding produces a “future price,” letting everyone in the chain know roughly where prices will be three or six months ahead.

2. Hedging (risk offset)  
   A steel mill worried about rising iron-ore costs buys iron-ore futures in advance;  
   A farm worried about falling corn prices sells corn futures in advance.  
   Whatever happens to spot prices later, the company has locked in its cost or revenue and can focus on production.

3. Speculation and arbitrage  
   Investors who think prices will rise go long; those who think they’ll fall go short. Using margin, they control large exposure with small capital and profit from price swings. Arbitrageurs exploit price gaps between markets or contract months, nudging prices toward fairness.

In one sentence:  
Commodity futures is where goods get priced, risks get insured, and money keeps moving.

Commodity futures—covering agricultural, metal, and energy contracts—are key financial instruments whose price-discovery and hedging functions make them integral to modern finance. Their price swings guide trading decisions, and historical data let investors forecast direction and magnitude of moves to maximize returns.

[Website Name]: PubMed  
[Date]:  
Excerpt 1:  
Review  

. 1993 Dec;117(12):1208-14.

Affiliations

- 

PMID:

**8250690**

Review

## Apoptosis and necrosis. Basic types and mechanisms of cell death

L M Buja et al.  
Arch Pathol Lab Med.1993 Dec.

## Abstract

Apoptosis and necrosis are two fundamental types of cell death. Current knowledge indicates that the key mechanism of apoptosis is endonuclease activation leading to internucleosomal double-stranded chromatin (DNA) breaks, whereas the key mechanism of necrosis is cell membrane damage. The initial alterations of cellular metabolism and electrolyte homeostasis induced by an injurious agent may activate at least four major pathways leading to loss of membrane integrity: membrane phospholipid degradation, production of amphipathic lipids, damage to the cytoskeleton, and generation of toxic oxygen species and free radicals. These insights point the way for further research to establish definitive causes of specific types of cell injury and cell death, and they provide important clues for the design of improved diagnostic approaches and therapeutic interventions.

messages.content:
Based on existing literature, systematic research directly targeting “Innovation Efficiency Evaluation of Hubei-listed Enterprises and Its Influencing Factors from the Perspective of New-Quality Productive Forces” remains scarce, yet several related studies offer key clues that can be integrated and extended:

---

### 1. Current Status of Innovation-Efficiency Evaluation for Hubei-Listed Enterprises

1. **Research foundation**  
Using 2017 annual-report data of 66 Hubei-listed firms, scholars applied **DEA** to assess **technological innovation efficiency** by ownership type and industry. Results show **pure technical and scale efficiencies are generally low**; R&D personnel and capital inputs fail to translate effectively into innovation outputs, indicating structural misallocation of innovation resources.

2. **Methodological implications**  
Although the “new-quality productive forces” lens was not explicitly adopted, the input–output efficiency measurement provides a baseline model. Future work can incorporate **super-efficiency SBM** or **DEA–Malmquist indices**, integrating core new-quality elements (novel technologies, green efficiency, new labor instruments) to build a finer evaluation system.

---

### 2. Influencing Factors from the New-Quality Productive-Forces Perspective

1. **Intra-firm elements matter**  
Recent findings reveal heterogeneous sensitivity to new-quality components:
- **SOEs**: most sensitive to **novel technology** (Sobol index = 0.3168); tech innovation is pivotal.  
- **Private firms**: rely more on **new labor objects** and **green efficiency**.  
- **Foreign firms**: most responsive to **new labor objects** (e.g., entry into new industries).

2. **External factors are also critical**  
- **Digital economy** exerts a significant positive effect, with stronger moderating impacts in highly urbanized regions.  
- **Corporate financialization** displays a clear “crowding-out” effect: excessive financial investment displaces R&D funds, **suppresses innovation efficiency**, and hampers new-quality productive forces—especially pronounced in central and western China.
Using the Analytic Hierarchy Process and fuzzy comprehensive evaluation

Alright, to answer your question more systematically, I will first construct an indicator system for “the innovation efficiency of listed companies in Hubei Province from the perspective of new-quality productive forces.” This system will serve as the foundation for applying the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and fuzzy comprehensive evaluation. I will integrate the core connotations of “new-quality productive forces”—such as technological breakthrough, factor innovation, and environmental friendliness—into the assessment of innovation efficiency, and structure it into a goal layer, criterion layer, and indicator layer. To ensure the indicators are scientific and comprehensive, I will first search the relevant literature to identify commonly used evaluation indicators in current research, and then adjust them to the characteristics of listed companies in Hubei Province.

Alright, please send the material that needs translation. I will translate each item into English and compile them into an Excel sheet with the following format:

| Summary Title | English | Chinese |

Go ahead and send the content.

Noon on an African dry riverbed: a chimpanzee leaps onto a hippo’s back, fists hammering, shrieking “ooh-ooh” for a bite of watermelon. The lazy hippo bucks, the ape slides off like a failed surfer, thrashes through the mud, crawls out with only a bruised backside.

Siberian taiga at dawn: the chimp flexes, tries to bend a moose’s antlers. The moose lowers its head, spears the ape square in the chest—thud—launches it three metres up to dangle from a branch, then drop into a snow cloud.

Australian red-earth dusk: the chimp wants the kangaroo’s shade, spins a flying kick. The roo’s spring-loaded legs snap back, boot the ape ten metres through the sand; the roo calmly settles again.

Amazon night in torrential rain: the chimp swings a log at a crocodile; the tail whips, splinters the wood, slams the ape sideways five metres into the mud, a living statue.

South-African coast evening: the chimp tries to steal a sea-lion’s fish; the seal belly-flips, tail-smacks the ape’s forehead; dizzy, it tumbles off the rocks.

Yellowstone dawn: the chimp taunts a grizzly; the bear’s paw swats it like a shuttlecock into the snow, where it stays.

African grassland night: the chimp grabs a warthog’s tusks; the hog charges, gores, chases the screaming ape fifty metres.

Mongolian steppe dawn: the chimp charges a camel herd; a hoof meets its backside, somersaults it into the sand, the camels march on.

Borneo swamp morning: the chimp punches a crocodile; the jaws snap, the ape scampers up a tree while the beast circles below.

Australian outback noon: the chimp chases an emu; the bird’s backward kick plants in the ape’s chest, rolls it into cactus spines.

Patagonian plateau: the chimp baits a puma; the cat judo-flips it, walks away.

Mongolian evening: the chimp tries to ride a camel; a hind-leg punt sends it five metres into a haystack.

Galápagos underwater: a sea-lion chases an octopus; ink blots its eyes, it smacks into a reef.

Patagonia again: a puma springs at a guanaco; the llama spits, blinds the cat, which yelps into a cactus.

Minus-twenty dawn: a moose collapses a beaver dam; the beaver slaps ice shards like bullets until the moose flees.

Afternoon: a bear raids the dam; the beaver latches onto its nose, is flung three metres, still snarling, and the bear retreats.

A capybara gnaws the dam; the beaver tail-whacks it into a mud ball.

A lynx stalks the dam; the beaver lever-launches it into the torrent.

A reindeer breaks the ice; the beaver pelts its legs with ice darts, the deer crashes.

A boar digs the bank; the beaver yanks a stick, the pig tumbles into the river.

On the plain, an oryx butts a warthog; both limp away.

A leopard pounces on a porcupine; quills in muzzle and rump, the cat flees howling.

Riverbank: hippo charges drinking chimp; ape vaults aboard, pounds the head, hippo rolls, water flies, antelope bolt.

Savanna: hyenas corner a baby chimp; silverback swings a log, scatters them.

Porcupine bristles; chimp grabs its tail, flings it into bushes.

Brown bear attacks; chimp sidesteps, punches the nose, bear retreats.

Red desert: kangaroo taunts; chimp leaps, mid-air kick sends it five metres, mob stares.

Baby elephant steals bananas; silverback hugs the leg, flips it, dust cloud, mother herds calf away.

Baboon snatches fruit; chimp rapid-punches, baboon’s face balloons, flees up a tree.

Cheetah stalks infant; chimp kicks its flank, cheetah bolts.

Antelope gores; chimp twists the horns, hurls it off.

Crocodile lunges; chimp clubs it with a sapling, reptile dives.

Rhino rampages; chimp beats it away with a stick.

Warthog charges; chimp jumps, double-hammers its back, hog kneels, squeals off.

Ostrich pecks; chimp spin-kicks its neck, bird pirouettes, feathers fly, runs.

Snippet1:
## **Traditional Healthcare Staffing Models**

For decades, most healthcare staffing models have relied upon three primary approaches: full-time employees, per diem staffing, and temporary agency staffing. Each offers certain advantages as well as limitations.

### **Overview of Traditional Staffing Models Like FTEs, Per Diem, Temporary, etc.**

Full-time employees (FTEs) encompass staff who work regular, predictable schedules - often 40 hours per week. Salaries or hourly wages compensate them predictably. FTEs are scheduled in advance by managers to fill recurring staffing needs.

Per diem employees work more variable schedules based on fluctuating demand. They may work a few shifts per month or per week on an as-needed basis. Per diem staff receive hourly pay for the hours worked rather than a guaranteed salary.

Temporary agency staffing involves partnering with external staffing agencies that contract travel and international healthcare professionals, usually nurses, to fill vacancies ranging from a single shift to permanent placement. Agencies manage recruitment and pay.

### **Full-Time Employees**

Full-time staffing delivers stability and continuity of care. Patients see the same regular faces each time they visit. FTEs allow managers to plan schedules weeks or months in advance. In-depth training and professional development investments are made due to their long-term tenure. However, FTE staffing lacks flexibility. It can become costly if patient volumes and facility utilization fluctuate significantly throughout the year. Having to overstaff for peak periods and under-scheduling during lower volume times leads to inefficiency.

### **Per Diem Employees**

Per diem staffing provides useful flexibility to scale up or down based on daily needs. Nurses can be called off or asked to work extra shifts due to census changes. Per diem models work well for departments like the ER where patient volume swings wildly. However, extensive per diem use can lead to less staff cohesion and continuity for patients. Investment in training and growth may be limited. Finding per diem staff willing to work overnight shifts, holidays, or weekends can be challenging. **‍**## **Traditional Healthcare Staffing Models**

### **Temporary Agency Staff**

Bringing on temporary agency nurses offers quick solutions to fill gaps from leaves, seasonal fluctuations, or other short-term spikes in demand. Agencies can recruit hard-to-fill specialties in high-need areas like ICU or ER nurses. Orientation may be expedited, and temporary staff may not be familiar with a healthcare facility's culture. Labor costs may fluctuate based on market conditions. However, by partnering with a reputable healthcare staffing agency, these issues can be avoided.

### **The Pros and Cons of These Traditional Approaches**

While traditional staffing models have served healthcare organizations well historically, reliance on just FTEs, per diem staff, and temporary agency nurses has inherent limitations that constrain effectiveness today:

-  FTE staffing lacks nimble flexibility to adjust for fluctuating patient volumes. Significant ramp-up/ramp-down time is required to change levels.

-  Per diem models, while flexible, can present engagement and training challenges for staff who work minimal hours. Finding specialty per diem staff willing to take less desirable shifts proves difficult.

-  None of these traditional approaches provide access to specialized clinical skills on demand when needs suddenly arise.

-  These models make it difficult to leverage innovations like telehealth, remote work, and cross-training without disrupting norms.

Relying solely on legacy approaches today often leaves healthcare leaders frustrated by ongoing staffing inadequacies and inefficiencies.## **Why Traditional Models are Proving Inadequate for Many Healthcare Organizations Today**

### **Internal Travel/Contingent Nurse Model**

Some leading systems are hiring experienced travel nurses for full-time internal contingent roles – also known as internal resource pool management or IRP. These nurses work flexible, customizable schedules spanning multiple sites and specialties. This taps into the specialty skills of career travel nurses within one’s own organization. Benefits include:

-  Increased retention compared to external travel nurses.

-  Eliminates travel nurse onboarding and learning curve.

-  Enables internal temporary staffing without external spending.

-  Provides staffing consistency even as nurses work across settings.

-  Expands benefits access for contingent roles.

Nurses gain staff status, development opportunities, and schedule control. **‍**

### **Remote Staffing Models and Telehealth**

Remote telehealth options enable clinical staff like providers, nurses, health coaches, and pharmacists to work from anywhere. Remote staff can perform tele-visits, monitor patients digitally, conduct online chart reviews, manage phone triage lines, and more. Benefits include:

-  Dramatically expands talent pool and access to scarce skills like mental health.

-  Allows site-independent productivity.

-  Reduces campus footprint needs.

-  Enables rapid scaling up or down.

-  Provides staff location flexibility, improving satisfaction.

Does require investments in technical infrastructure, training, and modifying workflows.

### **On-Demand Digital Staffing Platforms**

New digital health platforms are emerging that allow hospitals to instantly submit staffing requests and have qualified nurses or other clinicians ready for needed shifts within hours.  Resource pool management provides talent access with advantages like:

-  Immediately fills unexpected open shifts.

-  Eliminates short-notice staff scramble.

-  Enables temporary staffing without travel nurse overhead.

-  Provides access to specialized skills like OR nurses.

-  Integrates with existing HR systems.

Drawbacks can include onboarding challenges and limited staff familiarity.## **Overview of Each Emerging Model and How It Can Benefit Healthcare Staffing**

The innovative healthcare workforce models profiled earlier directly address many of the pressing pain points faced by traditional legacy staffing strategies:

**Centralized Float Pools**

Centralized float pool models provide numerous advantages compared to fragmented staffing approaches:

-  Greatly increase flexibility and agility to adjust RN and other staff levels up or down rapidly based on real-time demand changes. Decrease reliance on external travel nurses for flexibility.

-  Enable smoother staff redeployment across different facilities, specialties, and shifts. Break down silos between departments.

-  Reduce expenses by significantly decreasing reliance on premium-rate external travel nurse agencies to fill gaps. Internal float pools contain costs.

-  Standardized training and care protocols allow float pool staff to adapt quickly across service lines. This helps to smooth transition friction.

-  Provide expanded development opportunities for staff through cross-training. Builds career skills.

-  Increase staff engagement and retention by providing workplace variety and choice. **‍**

**Internal Travel Nurses**

Converting the traditional travel nurse model into an internally or externally managed resource pool provides advantages such as:

-  Increased retention compared to temporary contracted agency nurses. Reduces churn.

-  Decreases expenses and time associated with onboarding new external travel nurses.

-  Provides staffing consistency even as nurses flex across different facilities and shifts.

-  Expands benefits access and career development for these contingent roles.

-  Allows organizations to tap into specialized skills of career travel nurse talent in-house.

**Remote Telehealth Staffing**

Virtual clinical staffing delivers advantages such as:

-  Dramatically expands talent pool and access to specialized skills like mental health therapy previously constrained by geography.

-  Allows healthcare professionals to be productive on behalf of the organization regardless of physical location.

-  Reduces campus real estate and facility footprint needs.

-  Enables rapid scaling up or down of clinical staff to match evolving patient demand.

-  Provides staff with location flexibility, which aids recruitment and retention.

-  Reduces risk of staff exposure and transmission, especially for infectious diseases.

**On-Demand Digital Staffing**

Digital on-demand staffing platforms offer additional benefits like:## **Healthcare Staffing Solutions from Health Carousel**

### **FAQs**

**What are the main benefits of a float pool model in healthcare staffing?**

A float pool model in healthcare staffing refers to having a pool of staff such as nurses or allied health professionals that can move flexibly between departments and units as needed. Some of the main benefits of using a float pool include improved staffing flexibility, better coverage for staffing shortages, reduced costs associated with overtime, improved staff satisfaction, and enhanced skill development for the float pool nurses. The model allows healthcare organizations to move staff to areas experiencing higher patient volumes or staff shortages more efficiently. The float pool nurses also enjoy the variety and exposure to different specialties. Overall, a float pool model in healthcare staffing allows for better workload distribution and a more nimble approach to managing staffing needs and responding to fluctuations in patient volumes and acuity.

**How can I implement a remote healthcare staffing model?**

Implementing a remote healthcare staffing model requires careful planning and coordination. The first step is to evaluate which roles and specialties can effectively be staffed remotely versus requiring in-person care. For positions suited for remote work, such as telehealth nurses or coders, ensure staff have the technology, training, and protocols to provide quality care and meet legal compliance virtually. Create schedules that blend remote and on-site staff to maintain coverage and continuity of care. Provide remote staff opportunities to connect with the broader care team through video conferences, messaging, and periodic in-person meetings or events. Monitor productivity and patient satisfaction metrics to ensure the remote model is working effectively. With proper implementation focused on communication, technology, training, and blending remote and on-site staffing, healthcare organizations can build an effective remote staffing approach to expand access to care.

messages.content: How to delete a specific partition in ods_net_stat_ah_local in ClickHouse

To drop a specific partition of table `ods_net_stat_ah_local` in ClickHouse, use the `ALTER TABLE ... DROP PARTITION` statement.

### Syntax:
```sql
ALTER TABLE ods_net_stat_ah_local DROP PARTITION '<partition_id>';
```

### Steps:

#### 1. Confirm partition name
First list the partitions:
```sql
SELECT partition, name, active
FROM system.parts
WHERE table = 'ods_net_stat_ah_local' AND database = '<your_database>';
```

#### 2. Drop the partition
Suppose the partition to drop is `'202408'`:
```sql
ALTER TABLE ods_net_stat_ah_local DROP PARTITION '202408';
```

> ⚠️ Note:
> - The partition name must be a string, usually the corresponding date (e.g., `'20240801'` or `'202408'`), depending on your partition key.
> - Dropping a partition is irreversible; data is removed immediately.

#### 3. Optional: reclaim disk space immediately
ClickHouse cleans up dropped partitions asynchronously. To free space right away, trigger a merge or cleanup:
```sql
OPTIMIZE TABLE ods_net_stat_ah_local FINAL;
```

---

If you’re unsure about the partition name format, paste the output of the `system.parts` query and I’ll help you confirm.

messages.content:
Based on currently available sources, neither Japan nor South Korea publicly discloses exact prices for industrial steam; indirect data must be used for estimation.

### Japan  
Industrial steam is usually supplied by cogeneration plants or district-heating networks. Prices depend heavily on fuel cost, transport distance, and contract type (long-term or spot). Industry studies put **Japanese industrial steam at roughly 150–250 JPY/t** (≈ **7–12 CNY/t**) for large, long-term contracts.

### South Korea  
No official standard price exists. Data from KOGAS and energy markets indicate **industrial steam at about 20,000–30,000 KRW/t** (≈ **100–160 CNY/t**) when produced by gas boilers or cogeneration. Actual quotes vary with volume, delivery mode, and contract terms.

### Summary (CNY per tonne)

| Country | Industrial Steam Price Range |
|---------|-----------------------------|
| Japan   | 7–12 CNY                    |
| Korea   | 100–160 CNY                 |

> Figures are estimates; confirm with local utilities or park operators and expect them to move with energy-market fluctuations.

There is trosky and no he doesn't want an eternal war for the revolution he wants support the other socialists, communists even without war.

I need to get a better picture of what a German-victory WW1 would have looked like, how the Bolsheviks might have survived at all in those circumstances, and what the economic/demographic baseline of a Russia shorn of its western borderlands would have been. I’ll also look for analogues to the Franco-Soviet relationship you posit (syndicalist France + Trotsky-led USSR) to see how much real diplomatic or industrial synergy existed between the two left-wing camps in the 1920-30s.

片段 1：
If Germany won WW1, and they intervened in the Russian Civil War, would they be able to defeat the Bolsheviks or would the Soviets still win the war in the end?

[搜索关键词]:Treaty of Brest-Litovsk if Germany victorious WW1 long-term

[编号]:[^3^]
[标题]:What if: Peace Treaty in the West after a German Victory in WW1
[网站名称]:My Country? Europe.
[日期]: 2017-06-06
片段 1：
We can’t know for sure what terms the German Empire might have imposed on its enemies in the West, had it emerged from the Great War in the position to dictate them. But speculation on the matter is often colored by the one peace treaty the Germans did sign, as victors: the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk.

### As in the East, so in the West?

This peace treaty was a brutal, annihilating peace forced upon Russia after their final assaults ultimately failed and were pushed back by the victorious German and Austro-Hungarian forces. The constant warfare for over 3 years also took its toll, and Russia had been forced to put down several serious rebellions in the 20th century before the First World War. A full-blown civil war was raging, and it was the Bolsheviks who accepted the harsh treaty. The Bolsheviks were forced to surrender the Baltic States to Germany, and they were forced to accept the liberation of Ukraine and pay a hefty sum to the Central Powers. The historian Spencer Tucker said that “the German General Staff had formulated extraordinarily harsh terms that shocked even the German negotiator.” – World War One, p. 225

This statement, along with the treaty itself, has lead people to believe that the Germans planned a similar fate for the Western powers, but is the truth that simple? If the Germans had managed to punch through in Belgium, and reach Paris (as they nearly did in 1914), they could find themselves in a position to demand whatever they wanted. It is known that the German lines were close to breaking in 1918, but so were the lines of France and the BEF, not to mention the Italians were reeling in the Veneto frontlines. The thinking seems to go that Germany imposed the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk on Russia simply because they were able to, and that they would likewise do the same on France if they could.

But let us look at this from the beginning, what the powers sought to gain in the East. The Central Powers had not originally planned to impose anything similar to Brest-Litovsk on Russia, so let us start there, and examine _why_ the peace was so incredibly harsh.### Prospective Treaty Aftermath

When the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk was signed the Russian Army was still intact. Russia had lost but a fraction of her territory to enemy occupation, and had equipment for an army of nearly ten million men. The fact that the Bolsheviks were able to create a juggernaut called the Red Army right after the removal of Russia from the war proves one very important fact; Russia was not anything like finished.

Germany was well aware of the Pandora’s Box whose lid she had thrown off of in the east. The Bolsheviks were no allies and nothing could be expected from them. Their promises were worthless. If Germany battered down France in the west what was there to stop ten million victorious Soviet soldiers from crashing into Germany after they had consolidated power? How would Germany deflect this threat?

Well it would be exceedingly difficult to do once the red tide came rolling her way. So efforts had to be made to take measures to defend herself against such an untrustworthy and chaotic neighbour as the Soviet Union. These measures were stripping Russia of the majority of her industrial resources, including most of her coal and iron together with the agricultural wealth of the Ukraine.

Some see this as Germany’s shameless theft of Russian land in her endless “Drang nach Osten.” It would be more accurate to say that Germany was rather more concerned to keep these resources out of the hands of such an unpredictable and unscrupulous group of men as the Bolshevik Party. Men who signed Brest-Litovsk without hesitation even while they made plans to march on Berlin. Men whose Machiavellian character Germany was quite right to take precautions against.

In the long term the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk would have severely weakened the Russian state. Without the majority of its operational coal and oil sources and the vast agricultural produce of the Ukraine, the Russian state would be forced to import these materials which would both weaken its finances and limit what it could sustain in the field. Since Germany could deny Russia access to the world’s oceans, it would also mean that once engaged in war the Russians could not obtain resources from anywhere except in the case of regaining the territory they had lost.

[搜索关键词]:Trotsky foreign policy permanent revolution vs socialism in one country

[编号]:[^4^]
[标题]:Socialism in one country
[网站名称]:wikipedia.org
[日期]: 2003-07-22
片段 1：
The defeat of all the 1917–1923 revolutions in Europe, except Russia, ended the Bolsheviks' and especially Lenin's hopes for an imminent world revolution. Lenin expressed this, stating he was not expecting a pre-defined date for other nations to achieve the same revolution in his 1918 _Letter to American Workers_.\[17\]

With the proletarian revolutions in other countries having been either crushed or altogether failed to materialize, the nascent Soviet Union found itself encircled by capitalist or pre-capitalist states. According to the interpretation of Lenin's writings by the exponents of socialism in one country, Lenin laid down a long-term future course of action for the nascent Soviet state and its vanguard the R.C.P.(B.), prioritizing strengthening the nascent Soviet state internally so as to ensure its survival. The plan was based on, firstly, building a close class alliance between the proletariat and the vast masses of the small peasantry (with assured proletarian leadership of the peasantry), and secondly, constructing a complete socialist society in Russia whilst patiently awaiting and aiding the worldwide class struggle to mature into a world revolution in order to hasten the final victory of socialism.

In his pamphlet, _The Impending Catastrophe and How to Combat It,_ Lenin argued that Russia had to overtake advanced countries in economic output as well as political advancement.\[18\]

In his speech delivered at the Plenum of the C.P.S.U.(B.), Stalin observed that the aforementioned was written by Lenin as early as in September 1917, on the eve of October Revolution, during the imperialist war.\[19\]

Opponents of this interpretation, notably Leon Trotsky, have contended that the Lenin quotes adduced in support of socialism on one country are taken out of context. They argue that in the 1915 article _On the Slogan for a United States of Europe_ the expression "triumph of socialism \[...\] possible in \[...\] a single capitalist country" in context refers only to the initial establishment of a proletarian political and economic regime and not to the eventual construction of a complete socialist society which would take generations. As for the quote from the 1923 article _On Cooperation_, Trotsky maintains that the passage speaking of "necessary and sufficient" prerequisites for the transition to socialism is concerned only with the "socio-organisational" and political prerequisites, but not with the "material-productive" and cultural ones which Russia still lacked.\[20\]Historian Isaac Deutscher in his biographical account of Stalin noted that Marxist theoreticians in the 1920s took a condescending view of Stalin's formulations and doctrine of "socialism in one country". Deutscher recounted a party meeting in which David Riazanov, Soviet historian and founder of Marx-Engels Institute derided Stalin with the words "Stop it Koba, don't make a fool of yourself. Everybody knows that theory is not exactly your field".\[21\]

According to political scientist Baruch Knei-Paz, Trotsky's theory of "permanent revolution" was grossly misrepresented by Stalin as defeatist and adventurist in antithesis to his proposed "socialism in one country" policy to secure victory during the succession struggle. Knei-Paz argued that Trotsky encouraged revolutions in Europe but was not at any time proposing "reckless confrontations" with the capitalist world.\[22\]

Stalin presented the theory of socialism in one country as a further development of Leninism based on Lenin's aforementioned quotations. In his 14 February 1938 article titled _Response to Comrade Ivanov_, formulated as an answer to a question of a "comrade Ivanov" mailed to _Pravda_ newspaper, Stalin splits the question in two parts. The first side of the question is in terms of the internal relations within the Soviet Union, whether it is possible to construct the socialist society by defeating the local bourgeoisie and fostering the union of workers and peasants.\[23\]

Stalin quotes Lenin that "we have all that is necessary for the building of a complete socialist society" and claims that the socialist society has for the most part been indeed constructed. The second side of the question is in terms of external relations and whether the victory of the socialism is "final", i.e. whether capitalism cannot possibly be restored. Here, Stalin cites Lenin that the final victory is possible only on the international scale and only with the help of the workers of other countries.\[23\]

Marxist historian Isaac Deutscher traces Stalin's socialism in one country policy to the publication of _The Foundations of Leninism_ which emphasized the policy of isolationism and economic development in opposition to Trotsky's policy of permanent revolution.\[24\]

In a 1936 interview with journalist Roy W. Howard, Stalin articulated his rejection of exporting the revolution and stated that "We never had such plans and intentions" and that "The export of revolution is nonsense".\[25\]\[26\]\[27\]

[搜索关键词]:Treaty of Brest-Litovsk if Germany victorious WW1 long-term

[编号]:[^5^]
[标题]:Treaty of Brest-Litovsk
[网站名称]:wikipedia.org
[日期]: 2001-10-03
片段 1：
Under the terms of the treaty, Russia lost control of Ukraine, Poland, Belarus, Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia, and its Caucasian provinces of Kars and Batum. The lands comprised 34% of the former empire's population, 54% of its industrial land, 89% of its coalfields, and 26% of its railways. The Soviet government also confirmed the independence of Finland, which it had recognized in January 1918, and pledged to end its war with the Ukrainian People's Republic, which the Central Powers had recognized under the prior Treaty of Brest-Litovsk (9 February 1918). A supplementary protocol signed in August 1918 required Russia to pay Germany war reparations of six billion marks. The treaty was controversial in Russia, giving a unifying cause to the White movement and opening a rift between the Bolsheviks and the Left Socialist-Revolutionaries, whose representatives withdrew from the Council of People's Commissars after its signing and later rebelled in the Left SR Uprising.

The treaty was annulled by the Armistice of 11 November 1918,\[1\] in which Germany surrendered to the western Allied Powers. Subsequent attempts by the Soviets to restore power in the lost territories during the Russian Civil War (1917–1922) had mixed results, with the Red Army being defeated in the independence wars of the three Baltic countries and in the Polish–Soviet War, but successfully conquering Belarus early on,\[2\] later achieving victory in its invasions of Azerbaijan, Armenia, and Georgia and in Ukraine. The border with Turkey established by the treaty was largely affirmed by the Treaty of Kars (1921). Under the Treaty of Rapallo (1922), Russia and Germany renounced all territorial and financial claims against each other.

The Russian borders established by the treaty bear an almost exact similarity to the post-1991 borders established after the fall of the Soviet Union.\[3\]

Lev Kamenev arriving at Brest-Litovsk### Soviet-German financial agreement of August 1918

For the Western Allied Powers, the terms that Germany had imposed on Russia were interpreted as a warning of what to expect if the Central Powers won the war. Between Brest-Litovsk and the point when the situation in the Western Front became dire, some officials in the German government and the high command began to favour offering more lenient terms to the Allied Powers in exchange for their recognition of German gains in the east.\[43\]

The treaty marked a significant contraction of the territory controlled by the Bolsheviks or that they could lay claim to as effective successors of the Russian Empire. While the independence of Poland was already accepted by them in principle, and Lenin had signed a document accepting the Finnish independence, the loss of Ukraine and the Baltics created, from the Bolshevik perspective, dangerous bases of anti-Bolshevik military activity in the subsequent Russian Civil War (1917–1923). However, Bolshevik control of Ukraine and Transcaucasia was, at the time, fragile or non-existent.\[44\]

Many Russian nationalists and some revolutionaries were furious at the Bolsheviks' acceptance of the treaty and joined forces to fight them. Non-Russians who inhabited the lands lost by Bolshevik Russia in the treaty saw the changes as an opportunity to set up independent states.

Immediately after the signing of the treaty, Lenin moved the Soviet government from Petrograd to Moscow to prevent Germany from capturing the Russian capital in the event of an invasion.\[45\]\[34\] Trotsky blamed the peace treaty on the bourgeoisie, the social revolutionaries,\[46\] Tsarist diplomats, Tsarist bureaucrats, "the Kerenskys, Tseretelis and Chernovs",\[47\] the Tsarist regime, and the "petty-bourgeois compromisers".\[48\]

The treaty opened a permanent rift between the Bolsheviks and Left SRs. In July 1918 the Left SRs assassinated German Ambassador Wilhelm von Mirbach in the hopes that it would induce Germany to annul the treaty, leading to the Left SR Uprising.\[49\]

A map of Europe in 1923 after the Russian Civil War, among other revolutions.

[编号]:[^6^]
[标题]:USSR-France Relationship (1919-1933) – UPSC World History Notes - Blog
[网站名称]:Edukemy
[日期]: 2023-11-25
片段 1：
## Improvement in Relations (After 1930)

-  _Reason_: The rise of the Nazis in Germany led to an increase in positivity in the Franco-Russian relationship.

## **Key Themes:**

### 1\. Treaty of Versailles and the Rise of Nazism

-  _Treaty’s Impact on Germany_:

	-  The Treaty of Versailles, though satisfying to the “Big Three” (US, Britain, and France), created resentment in Germany. It was viewed as an unjust peace, leaving Germany weakened but still potent enough to thwart communism.

-  _German Resentment_:

	-  Germans were particularly embittered by clauses blaming Germany for the war’s cause and the subsequent financial penalties imposed.

-  _Rise of Nazism_:

	-  The harsh conditions of the treaty fueled long-lasting resentment among Germans, contributing significantly to the rise of Nazism.

### 2\. US Policy of Isolation and the Great Depression’s Global Impact

-  _US Isolationism_:

	-  The United States adopted a policy of isolation, distancing itself from European political affairs.

-  _The Great Depression’s Global Effects_:

	-  The Great Depression, originating in the US, escalated into a worldwide economic crisis. This crisis profoundly influenced European political decisions for years, including their approaches to international relations.

[搜索关键词]:Germany wins WW1 consequences for Russia Bolsheviks

[编号]:[^7^]
[标题]:The Treaty of Brest-Litovsk | History of Western Civilization II
[网站名称]:Lumen Learning
[日期]: 
片段 1：
## 29.4.2: The Treaty of Brest-Litovsk

The Russian government collapsed in March 1917. The subsequent October Revolution followed by a further military defeat brought the Russians to terms with the Central Powers via the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk, which granted the Germans a significant victory and resulted in Russia exiting the war and breaking ties with the Allied Powers.

### Learning Objective

State the consequences of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk

### Key Points

-  In March 1917, demonstrations in Russia culminated in the abdication of Tsar Nicholas II and the appointment of a weak provisional government that shared power with the Petrograd Soviet socialists.

-  This arrangement led to confusion and chaos both at the front and at home, with the Russian army becoming increasingly ineffective.

-  Discontent and the weaknesses of the provisional government led to a rise in the popularity of the Bolshevik Party led by Vladimir Lenin, which demanded an immediate end to the war.

-  The October Revolution, which put the Bolsheviks into power, was followed in December by an armistice and negotiations with Germany.

-  At first, the Bolsheviks refused the German terms, but when German troops began marching across Ukraine unopposed, the new government acceded to the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk on March 3, 1918.

-  The treaty ceded vast territories, including Finland, the Baltic provinces, parts of Poland, and Ukraine, to the Central Powers.

-  The treaty was effectively terminated in November 1918 when Germany surrendered to the Allies.

[搜索关键词]:Treaty of Brest-Litovsk if Germany victorious WW1 long-term

[编号]:[^8^]
[标题]:Brest-Litovsk: Eastern Europe's Forgotten Father
[网站名称]:World War I Centennial
[日期]: 2015-12-28
片段 1：
#### **by Adrian Bonenberger**

Treaty of Brest Litovsk March 1918 map. Image courtesy of http://slideplayer.com/slide/4453652/

What seemed like strength, however, ended up being the opposite, and vice versa. Germany insisted on and received its demands, and then found itself forced to garrison its new territories with nearly a million soldiers, overstretching its military and potentially robbing itself of the means by which to force a conclusion to the war before substantial numbers of Americans could arrive.

The garrisoning of soldiers did not come without its own risks—although the Bolsheviks had reluctantly agreed to terms that were widely viewed as humiliating, and were no longer in open conflict with Germany, that did not stop local Bolsheviks or their socialist allies from attempting to radicalize Germany’s soldiers. Furthermore, ethnic nationalists in Ukraine and Belarus felt that they had been mislead, and began small-scale insurgencies. What had seemed originally like a boon to the German war effort quickly turned into a cultural and logistical nightmare.

**Long lasting effects**

While these immediate effects of Brest-Litovsk were playing out—soon to be overcome by events when Germany lost the war—it’s the longer-term implications of the treaty that are most relevant today. Chiefly, the establishment of a clear legal precedent for an Eastern Europe to exist independent of Russia, in a basic form that endures to this day, along the model of countries to its West—but also, the basis for that precedent being rooted in the ethnic, historical, and linguistic identity of the people inhabiting those places. Although “Ukrainian” and “Belarusian” culture were recognized as such long before Brest-Litovsk, those things had not been viewed as sufficient for self-sustaining cultures, then—on the contrary, those identities made Ukrainians, Belarusians, Estonians, Lithuanians, Latvians and (most of all, because of their powerful literary tradition) Poles exceptionally dangerous to Germany and to Russia. Germany facilitated the breaking of that longstanding tradition of subjugating Eastern European peoples, subsuming them into larger nations.

The Brest-Litovsk Treaty#### **by Adrian Bonenberger**

The Brest-Litovsk Treaty

The most immediate consequence, sadly for the Central Powers after their defeat, is that the same principles were applied to Germany and Austria-Hungary, and both countries were partitioned to create smaller nations (Germany much less so than Austria-Hungary, which was utterly destroyed). What had seemed like a good idea when applied to others was catastrophic when applied to them. And the scope of the Treaty of Versailles would likely not have been as sweeping or severe had not the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk been hovering over the proceedings.

So when you look at a map of Eastern Europe today, you’re looking at something fairly similar to the map drawn up by negotiators sitting around tables about 100 years ago, dreaming of a German empire, or of a worker-led socialist revolution. Funny how things work out.

**And the circumstances explain a lot**

A final point that’s worth making about Brest-Litovsk, Eastern Europe, and how it came about: the shape of those countries liberated or annexed by Germany were not put into their final form until 1946, for the most part, with pieces of Ukraine, Belarus, and Poland (to say nothing of Russia and Germany) shifting and changing repeatedly. In the case of Ukraine, if Russian occupation holds, one may be able to say that the shape of its country changed last in 2014.

But most of those changes were imposed externally; created by treaties or agreements by those larger powers. Few countries in Eastern Europe achieved independence or identity through war, or on their own terms, for better or for worse. Tim Snyder makes a compelling case in his book _Reconstruction of Nations_ that the closest “positive” national movement occurred in Poland’s handling of the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact and the end of the U.S.S.R.—by taking the initiative, unprompted, to relinquish outstanding potential claims on Ukrainian territory—that their action was itself a kind of positive national determination, that helped set the stage for further positive relationships between Eastern European countries. This was during a time when other areas, notably the former Yugoslavia, fell into extreme violence. There was no reason to believe or expect that would not be the case in Eastern Europe, especially given the two wars fought between Poland and Ukraine between 1918-19 and then 1943-46.

[搜索关键词]:Trotsky foreign policy permanent revolution vs socialism in one country

[编号]:[^9^]
[标题]:Permanent revolution
[网站名称]:wikipedia.org
[日期]: 2003-07-01
片段 1：
This article is about the theoretical term. For other uses, see Permanent Revolution.

**Permanent revolution** is the strategy of a revolutionary class pursuing its own interests independently and without compromise or alliance with opposing sections of society. As a term within Marxist theory, it was first coined by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels as early as 1850. Since then different theorists, most notably Leon Trotsky (1879–1940), have used the phrase to refer to different concepts.

Trotsky's permanent revolution is an explanation of how socialist revolutions could occur in societies that have not achieved an advanced capitalist mode of production. Trotsky's theory also argues that the bourgeoisie in late-developing capitalist countries are incapable of developing the productive forces in such a manner as to achieve the sort of advanced capitalism which will fully develop an industrial proletariat; and that the proletariat can and must therefore seize social, economic and political power, leading an alliance with the peasantry. Trotsky also opposed Joseph Stalin's principle of socialism in one country and stated that socialist revolutions needed to happen across the world in order to combat the global capitalist hegemony. According to Russian historian Vadim Rogovin (1937–1998), the success of Stalin's theoretical position had a significant and negative impact on the entire course of the international revolutionary process.\[1\]

Marx's view of "permanent" revolution sees revolutionary activity as continuously ongoing _until_ the revolutionary forces achieve a defined goal (such as socialism or communism).\[2\] This contrasts with the permanent (that is, ongoing _forever_) revolutionary activity envisaged in Maoist Continuous Revolution Theory.\[ _citation needed_\]## Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels

### Relation to Trotskyist theory

After the October Revolution, the Bolsheviks, now including Trotsky, did not discuss the theory of permanent revolution as such. However, its basic theses can be found in such popular outlines of communist theory as _The ABC of Communism_ which sought to explain the program of the Bolshevik Party by Yevgeni Preobrazhensky and Nikolai Bukharin. According to Russian historian, Vadim Rogovin, the leadership of the German Communist Party had requested that Moscow send Leon Trotsky to Germany to direct the 1923 insurrection. However, this proposal was rejected by the Politburo which was controlled by Stalin, Zinoviev and Kamenev who decided to send a commission of lower-ranking Russian Communist Party members.\[14\]

Later on after Lenin's death in the 1920s, the theory did assume importance in the internal debates within the Bolshevik Party and was a bone of contention within the opposition to Joseph Stalin. In essence, a section of the Bolshevik Party leadership, whose views were voiced at the theoretical level by Bukharin, argued that socialism could be built in a single country, even an underdeveloped one like Russia. Bukharin argued that Russia's pre-existing economic base was sufficient for the task at hand, provided the Soviet Union could be militarily defended.

The question of the Northern Expedition and the subjection of the Chinese Communist Party to control by the Kuomintang at the behest of the Bolshevik Party was a topic of argument within the opposition to Stalin in the party.\[15\] Figures such as Karl Radek argued that a stagist strategy was correct for China. (These writings were lost in the 1930s; if copies exist in the Soviet archives, they have not been located since the dissolution of the Soviet Union.) By contrast, Trotsky generalised his theory of permanent revolution, which had only been previously applied to Russia. He argued that the proletariat needed to take power in a process of uninterrupted and permanent revolution in order to not only carry out the tasks of the bourgeois-democratic revolution, but also to implement socialism.

messages.content:
You are Deepseek, an AI assistant.  
  
For logic questions like comparisons or counting, think step by step before answering.

Today is: Friday, August 15, 2025

各位早上好。请允许我先问大家一个问题：上一次，您陪父母看病或带孩子出游，心里最大的不安是什么？——是医院里“找不到、等不起、看不懂”，还是景区里“人挤人、千篇一律、拍完照就走”？那一瞬，我们突然意识到：技术再炫，如果解不了“人”的焦虑，就永远只是展厅里的玩具。

我是一位连续创业者，也是一位父亲。去年，母亲做肺部复查，我在三家医院间往返打印胶片；女儿想去敦煌，可排队两小时、参观十分钟的体验让她只记得“累”。那一刻，我决定把公司七年积累的AI空间智能技术，从实验室拉到真实世界——让“虚实共生”不再是口号，而是父母与孩子脸上的轻松。

破局，从“空间懂人”开始。

我们把医院物理空间1:1克隆成“AI孪生院”。患者进门，手机里的“就医分身”已替他排队、缴费、导航。检查做完，AI在3秒内把二维切片生成可互动的3D“数字器官”，医生与家属戴上MR眼镜，肿瘤位置、手术路径一清二楚。术后回家，病房“折叠”进家庭客厅，药盒、体征、康复动作实时同步，出现异常，AI先预警，医生再介入。试点三个月，患者平均院内停留时间缩短42%，家属请假天数减少一半——省下的，不只是钱，更是陪伴的尊严。

文旅，我们让“风景长在心里”。在良渚古城，游客戴上普通墨镜，5000年前的稻田、宫殿、祭祀瞬间叠到眼前；AI根据你的步速、视线、心率，实时生成专属路线：孩子多看一眼的玉琮，系统立刻弹出AR解谜游戏；老人走累了，脚边出现虚拟摇橹船，坐着就把下一站“漂”过去。离园时，个人“数字纪念册”已自动生成：一段你亲手挖掘的“数字玉璧”，可社交、可二创、可交易。今年五一，试点景区复游率提升58%，二次消费翻了三倍——游客说，终于“把文化带回家”。

虚实共生的底层，是“空间智能体”的三重进化：  
第一，毫米级定位，让虚拟信息像钉子一样钉在真实世界；  
第二，多模态意图理解，让系统“一眼看穿”你是谁、你要什么；  
第三，场景链式协同，把医院、景区、交通、商业的数据孤岛串成一条“体验链”。  
当技术隐入背景，人就被推到了前景。

今天，我们开放三大能力：空间孪生引擎、多模态交互框架、场景链数据协议，向所有医疗、文旅伙伴免费授权一年。京浙两地已启动“虚实共生”联合基金，单个项目最高支持3000万。我们希望，明年此时，当父母再需就医、孩子再想远行，焦虑不再写在他们的脸上，而是被AI悄悄接住。

虚实之间，隔的不是屏幕，是人心。当技术开始替我们排队、指路、讲解、守护，空间就有了温度。让我们一起，把医院还给健康，把景区还给故事，把宝贵的时间，还给爱与陪伴。

谢谢大家！

Sure, I’ll start with a quick reconnaissance: scan this year’s “Beijing-Zhejiang Talent 100 Summit” for its key focus, published agenda and speakers, plus the most talked-about “AI + healthcare/culture-tourism” rollouts of the past six months. That keeps the speech in sync with the summit’s context and embeds the freshest, most persuasive cases—moving the audience from empathy to breakthrough.
